While the game lacks any serious campaign or seems to lack any AI, its still very fun. War is simulated all the way to inventory and ammo of every individual soldier on the battlefield. 

There is "campaign", which consists of more or less 10 "missions" for every nation. They are all the same, scripted three scenarios: You assault your enemy sitting on entrenched positions, with some reinforcements attacking you mindlessly, or your enemy attacks your 4 entrenched positions, also mindlessly, or you defend and have the freedom to make your own defense line.
absolutely amazing game, even without the fantastic mods this game really does hold up very well, you buy this if you have the chance because im sure you will not regret it

Very good game. It is extremely detailed. You can command each unit individually, view the respective inventory, and set formations and orders.

The menu is a bit confusing, there isn't really a tutorial and the game isn't entirely beginner-friendly, but the complex options outweigh any disadvantages. It's a really good RTS, really worth it.

Every faction is different. There are also very nice and adjustable graphics. The sound is also very good, as are the controls. Overall the gameplay is very good. A test is definitely worth it.

God my last reply was very very horrid... Anyways, time for a revamped review!

Basic Review:
First, let's start with the basics of MOWAS2. Men of War in general is a RTS-based game where you take place in the WWII era. Either be it Japan, Britain, America, Germany, or Russia. My time on MOW is very limited, so I may not have the best review but it works for me. 

Modding:
The modding community is very well built and made. The modding system varies off on your computer and the workshop, so spend it wisely. I suggest some 3-5 mods for a good experience in the modding community. (Two main mods, and one or two smaller mods for patches or better quality of graphics.) The modding platform consists of mainly extra troopers, vehicles, and other such types of units. 

Gameplay:
The gameplay of Men of War is very straightforward, only needing slight brainpower to handle. You hold a left-click to select some units and right-click on an area to move them forward. Right-clicking next to barricades, broken down cars or tanks, buildings, or walls will make them border it. They will take spots and use them for cover. If you have a group of two or three units, put them in crater holes or cars. If you have five to six units, put them beside trucks, walls, and crater holes. If you have a total of ten units, put them inside buildings, behind broken-down tanks, and trucks, or put them beside bushes to set up an ambush. W-A-S-D may or may not work to move the camera, so it's just better to drag your mouse across your desk to move the camera. I highly doubt people on mobile or IPads will see this, so, I wouldn't worry about that. However to be nice, just drag your finger over the big screen to move the camera. (Hopefully.)

Every faction has a different set of weaponry. Spanding from the Second World War, stretching from Lugers to M1911 Machine Guns, there are very well lots of weapons to choose from. There are also lots of tanks, planes and also even artillery. 

Conclusion
Men of War is a very vast and expansive game. With lots of equipment, units, different mechanics to enform you and also lots of modding that you can choose. What I like about Men of War, is that they really tried with this game, and, to me it worked flawlessly. Sure, there may be a few bugs here and there, but in general the game is pretty fine and well shaped. Afterall, I only scratched the surface on what you're able to do in Men of War! Thank you for looking at my pointless ramble and review. :)

As this being my first RTS I've played, and yes I know I don't have much experience of the entire game, but from where I'm at now this game is really good. The ability to multitask your squads to together work simultaneously to complete the objective is very cool to see. You have to know what is going on and where your squads are at all times otherwise your gonna get steamrolled (depends on difficulty). You have to be cautious of your point spending as you only get so much when a mission starts and until you start capturing enemy points you won't get a lick of points back. Plus there is A LOT of content in this game, multiple campaign factions to choose from each with their own set of unique missions and units/vehicles.  I'll come back to this review once I have more experience to this game and add onto it but its a very good game and I would recommend it!

Geopolitical theory, a multifaceted discourse, navigates the intricate web of global power dynamics. At its nucleus lies the perennial struggle for supremacy, wherein nation-states engage in a perpetual dance of strategic calculus, propelled by imperatives of security, resources, and influence. This essay endeavors to dissect the labyrinthine contours of geopolitical thought, delving into paradigms that elucidate the relentless interplay of statecraft on the world stage.

Historically, geopolitical thinkers such as Halford Mackinder and Nicholas Spykman have proffered seminal frameworks, positing the centrality of geographic determinism in shaping international affairs. Mackinder's Heartland Theory, a geopolitical sine qua non, contends that control over the Eurasian landmass confers dominion over the "World-Island" and, by extension, global hegemony. Conversely, Spykman's Rimland Theory challenges this orthodoxy, emphasizing maritime power and the pivotal role of coastal fringes in geopolitical maneuvering.

The geopolitical landscape, however, is not static; it evolves with the ebbs and flows of socio-political currents. The post-Cold War era ushered in a reevaluation of traditional paradigms, with scholars like Samuel Huntington introducing the clash of civilizations as a framework for understanding geopolitical fault lines. This paradigm posits that cultural and religious identities, rather than strictly territorial considerations, drive geopolitical conflicts in the contemporary era.

Furthermore, the rise of non-state actors and the asymmetrical nature of modern warfare have injected complexity into the geopolitical milieu. Transnational threats, be they cyber-espionage, terrorism, or pandemics, defy traditional state-centric analyses, necessitating a paradigm shift towards a more nuanced understanding of power dynamics in an interconnected world.

Moreover, economic forces exert a profound influence on geopolitical outcomes. The burgeoning significance of globalization has intertwined the fortunes of nations, rendering economic power an indispensable component of geopolitical ascendency. States strategically leverage economic instruments, such as trade agreements and sanctions, to wield influence and advance their geopolitical objectives.

In conclusion, geopolitical theory, a mélange of historical legacies and contemporary exigencies, provides a lens through which we discern the intricacies of global power dynamics. From the deterministic propositions of Mackinder to the cultural paradigms delineated by Huntington, the intellectual tapestry of geopolitical thought continues to evolve, mirroring the dynamic nature of international relations. In an era characterized by unprecedented connectivity and multifaceted threats, the imperative to comprehend and navigate the complexities of geopolitics remains paramount for policymakers and scholars alike.

The game itself is fantastic. After spending about 150+ hours in the main campaign, I decided to check out the custom map editor. I made a map and even downloaded a few. The problem came in when I tried actually to play the maps, and OH BOY, there's virtually no way to play them. I've been trying for hours now to figure out where the skirmish is saved so I can force the map into the generic load file, but I can't figure that out either. 

And lord oh mighty! Good luck googling it because, for some reason, there's not a single video or thread explaining it. I did, however, come across other people asking the same question but was only met with people asking, "WTF are you posting on such an old thread?" Dude! It's only two years old, and who gives a da*n how old the thread is if the question is valid? People, I swear.

Wouldn't pay $30 (would say <$10 would be appropriate)  for it but it can be fun. However, the game feels unfinished. And by unfinished, I don't mean "kind of buggy and could use some polish" I mean it feels like parts of the game are missing. Like the AI, it feels like the game doesn't really have an actual opponent, it just has you assault preplaced units and occasionally sends a new unit to drive towards your line.  The maps are often too narrow for any flanking or creative maneuvers. 
Not great for a RTS to not have strategy.
Mods are an absolute MUST to enjoy the game, otherwise it feels very content barren and repetitive.

This review is a look mostly on my time playing the single player game mode.

reasons why i like it is: 
-the intimate squad level to large scale troop control
-interface simplicity

cons:

Men of War: Assault Squad 2 - A Brutal Dance of Tactics and Bullets

Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is a hardcore tactical real-time strategy game that throws you into the brutal realities of World War II squad-based combat. It's not for the faint of heart, demanding careful planning, precise execution, and a healthy dose of luck to emerge victorious from its unforgiving battlefields.

Strengths:

Unparalleled Tactical Depth: Unlike other RTS games where you command large armies, Men of War: Assault Squad 2 focuses on small, tightly-knit squads. Every soldier under your command is an individual with strengths, weaknesses, and a fragile life hanging in the balance. Every decision you make, from cover placement to weapon selection, can have a profound impact on the outcome of a firefight.

Granular Realism: The game strives for an almost unsettling level of realism. Ballistics are meticulously simulated, meaning every shot matters. Friendly fire is a very real threat, and cover isn't just a suggestion – it's a necessity. You'll need to utilize terrain, flanking maneuvers, and combined arms tactics to overcome your enemies.

Intense Multiplayer: The game's multiplayer mode is where it truly shines. Coordinating with your squadmates to execute complex flanking maneuvers, laying down suppressing fire, and calling in devastating artillery strikes is a thrilling and rewarding experience.

Weaknesses:

Steep Learning Curve: The game's depth and complexity can be overwhelming for newcomers. The multitude of hotkeys, tactical options, and unforgiving mechanics can lead to a frustrating initial experience.
Technical Issues: The game can be prone to occasional bugs and glitches, which can be immersion-breaking in the heat of battle.
Repetitive Missions: While the core gameplay loop is engaging, some of the campaign missions can feel repetitive after a while, with similar objectives and settings.
Overall:

Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is a challenging but rewarding tactical RTS experience for players who enjoy the intricacies of squad-based combat and the satisfaction of outsmarting their opponents. If you're willing to invest the time to learn its ropes and embrace its unforgiving nature, you'll find a deep and rewarding game that offers unparalleled tactical depth and an intense multiplayer experience.

Verdict: 4 out of 5 stars

Recommendation:

Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is recommended for hardcore RTS fans who enjoy a steep learning curve, realistic combat, and intense tactical challenges. If you're looking for a casual pick-up-and-play experience, you might want to look elsewhere.

Tips for New Players:

Start with the tutorials and training missions to learn the basics of the game's mechanics and controls.
Don't be afraid to experiment with different tactics and squad compositions.
Utilize cover to your advantage. Every soldier lost is a valuable asset gone.
Communication is key in multiplayer. Coordinate with your teammates to execute effective strategies.
Don't get discouraged by initial defeats. The game has a steep learning curve, but mastering its tactical depth is immensely rewarding.
I hope this review helps you decide whether Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is the right game for you.

bruh!

this is one of th most unique RTS games out there! plus its good to boot! ive been playing rts games since return fire (DOS) and this is one of the best ive ever experienced. 

one of the most unique features is the direct control function. most rts games consist of move here, attack this, use this ability. however if th unit performs poorly then ur just SOL. in this game u can take control of th unit and take ur fate into ur own hands! wat do i mean? well if u take direct control of a tank then u drive it (wasd), control its facing with such,and can switch between its weapons while firing them manually which also allows u to see effective range markers and LOF. super frign dope imo.

theres a lot more to this game as well which make it stand out, like being able to look into a units inventory (which very few rts games allow), u can control stances (prone crouch, etc)stripping weapons and items from dead, heal dying units...like theres a lot to this game. the armor has dynamic points that can take damage so if ur tracks get damged ur stuck until u either hop out and fix it OR send a unit over to do th repairs. crew died but the armor is still not destoyed? cool, send a team to repair and recrew it, can even steal enemy armor if th crew is cleared :) infantry units usually have a field medic embedded in the teams, but if he goes down ur gona hafta use a different teams medic to save ur fallen men. ALSO u can mix and match infantry teams however u like! its pretty micro heavy but u can literally pull specific men from their unit. wana keep all ur medics together? pull each one outa their respective teams. want an entire smg squad? more of the same.  u can customize to ur hearts delight. dope


now for the big bad downside. this game offers no comp stomp skirmish. so outside of playing the missions there is no custom game function WITH AI, theres custom mp but for some reason th devs opted to leave out custom skirmishs vs computer. big whiff there. *edit* it exists, but only as a fugn paid dlc, big thumbs down, nearly un-recommended for that nickle and dime bs

also the missions and achievements all follow the same patterns. while each mission is fairly different in its own way (defend, assault, wave defense, elite infiltration and sabotage, etc), each faction has the same exact string of missions. 1st mission is a short defense followed by an all out assault, the second is a point capture assault, 3rd is a wave defense and so on. theres like 6 factions each with unique units which makes each experience unique, but the missions themselves are very cut and pastey.

this game is VERY micro intensive

Everything that you thought had meaning, every hope, dream, or moment of happiness. None of it matters as you lie bleeding out on the battlefield. None of it changes what an artillery round does to a body. We all die. But does that mean our lives are meaningless. Does that mean that there was no point in our being born? Would you say that of our slain comrades? What about their lives, were they meaningless? They were not, their memory serves as an example to us all! The courageous fallen, the anguished fallen, their lives have meaning because we, the living refuse to forget them and as we ride to certain death, we trust our successors to do the same for us! Because my soldiers do not buckle or yield when faced with the cruelty of this world! MY SOLDIERS PUSH FORWARD! MY SOLDIERS SCREAM OUT! MY SOLDIERS RAGE!!!

I must admit, I was skeptical about Men of War: Assault Squad 2. I am sort of a fanatic when it comes to WW2 era games and pledged my loyalty to Company of Heroes 1 and 2 and swore to myself it is hands down the best of its genre in this age and time. I had been playing CoH for many years(13) on and off. Eventually I got an insane itch to buy a new WW2 era game and came across this one, noticing an "Overwhelmingly Positive" rating score while viewing trailers and reading the game descriptions. 

         I have never been so wrong about what I pledged. I purchased and played MoW: AS2 for HOURS. It is a tremendous, colossal, ridiculously good improvement. Albeit, there are pros and cons, but when you run into anything distasteful while playing this game  just exit game, visit the workshop, and turn support the committed MODDING community. You can basically mod this into a completely different game over and over again until you find something you really like or something that challenges the steeliest of nerves.
Very good RTS game, attention to detail is top notch and gameplay is great, also quite of bit of mods out there. Highly recommend shows how simple RTS genre is becoming these days.
One of the best strategy games.

Hands down the best WW2 Tactical strategy game of all time especially with the mod install called RobZ realism it's play host to some epic intense, white knuckle battles.

-Can control units individual and make your own squad compositions
- Each solider has there own inventory, it's possible to rip an MG42 off a dead german tank and Slap it on your Sherman or have infantry use it.
-Game has direct control mode for all units, it's possible to manually shoot and cook and throw grenades.
-overall it's very intense tactical game, fairly hardcore and game is even better with mods like RobZ realism.
- has good key binds for solider controls and unit switching.
Pain and Suffering, the true WW2 General Experience

This is a very solid near perfect RTS plus  micro-management game set in the Theatres of World War 2. The real down-side to the game is the Skrimish Missions become poignantly repetitive as you progress through the nations. The Map designs are well built but aethestics wise they are not as polished compared to games like Company of Heroes 2 & British Expansion, this game does not live to the strategic vibe of Hearts of Iron IV. However, this game is has a huge learning curve that I delightfully highly enjoyed in contrast to Company of Heroes 1 & 2 micro-management learning curve is not as intensive as Men of War Assault Squad 2, I feel the players playing Ranked & Unranked online Matches are bit too intense with the tension of wining while forgetting to enjoy this WW2 game as it is because this game's mechanics is one pearl that live beyond ahead of it's time.

The game is still Have significantly Less BUGS' than Gates of HELL Ostfront. I can't believe i say this XD

I watched hours of modded Men of War Assault Squad 2 growing up. I especially enjoyed the Star Wars Mod. I dreamed of playing this game someday. Sadly, I was pretty disappointed with it. I still think it’s a good game for its time but setting up my own custom battles and making my own custom maps and using mods was not easy. I spent more time messing with the editor than playing and still never made any particularly impressive maps or battles. I eventually lost all interest in the game because the editor was just too damn janky. Also, the missions are pretty meh. I also really wanted to try the multiplayer but lost interest in the game before I got around to trying it. I might come back and try a little multiplayer.

I played a few LAN 1V1s back in the day and jumped back in playing through the campaigns a short while ago.
The game is a little [i]like[/i] CoH if you've played that.
What I really enjoy is taking over a unit for the kill shot.  Watching that AP round punch through the side of a tank and seconds later the turret blowing off is pretty darn satisfying.
This game runs fine and is stable I would say.  I haven't crashed.
There a few buggy things like some pathing and units can stall a second in single player.   
Graphics, sounds and campaigns are good.  The normal speed seems fast.
I cannot play on normal speed most of the time.  I micro too much and am just slow so no PVP.
It would be cool to FP when you take command of your solder or tank.  MoW2 will have that feature I believe.
I picked a few mods to see how they are and wow, these mod Dev's are something.
The workshop adds so much but you still might want to pick up DLCs.  Personally I would wait for a sale.  
Have had plenty fun in the hours I've played.
I am going to recommend Men of War: Assault Squad 2.

[h1]Men of War: Assault Squad 2 - Tactical Havoc and the Art of Turning Soldiers into Unlikely Acrobats[/h1]

[h2]Rating: ★★★★☆[/h2]

Playing Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is like orchestrating a symphony of chaos where your soldiers are both the musicians and the stuntmen. It's a tactical dance of bullets, explosions, and occasionally soldiers performing unexpected aerial maneuvers that would make Cirque du Soleil proud. Grab your helmet, it's time for a strategic circus!

[h3]Pros:[/h3]

1. [b]Deep Tactical Gameplay:[/b] Men of War: Assault Squad 2 isn't just a game; it's a thinking person's battlefield. Planning your moves is like playing chess, but with tanks, snipers, and the occasional airborne soldier.

2. [b]Realistic Physics:[/b] The physics engine is a comedic genius. It's like watching a physics-based comedy show where soldiers occasionally defy gravity in the most unexpected ways, adding a touch of humor to the battlefield.

3. [b]Variety of Units:[/b] The game offers a vast array of units, from infantry squads to tanks and artillery. It's like having a tactical toolbox where every unit is a different tool for wreaking havoc.

4. [b]Multiplayer Mayhem:[/b] Multiplayer mode is like entering a strategic battleground where every opponent is a cunning tactician. It's a pixelated chessboard where the pieces are armed to the teeth.

5. [b]Modding Community:[/b] Men of War: Assault Squad 2 has a vibrant modding community. It's like having access to an ever-expanding toy chest, where new maps, units, and scenarios keep the game fresh.

[h3]Cons:[/h3]

1. [b]Steep Learning Curve:[/b] The learning curve is like scaling a tactical mountain. Newcomers might feel like they're navigating a minefield of buttons and commands until they master the art of war.

2. [b]Occasional Pathfinding Issues:[/b] Soldiers, while generally competent, can occasionally channel their inner clowns with questionable pathfinding decisions. It's like watching a pixelated circus act where soldiers take the scenic route to battle.

3. [b]Graphics Showing Age:[/b] The graphics, while functional, have aged a bit. It's like watching an old war movie; the storytelling is excellent, but you occasionally notice the wrinkles.

4. [b]Micro-Management Intensity:[/b] The game can be intense on the micro-management front. It's like conducting an orchestra, but instead of instruments, you're coordinating soldiers, tanks, and artillery.

5. [b]Single-Player AI Quirks:[/b] While formidable, the single-player AI can occasionally exhibit quirks. It's like sparring with an unpredictable opponent who occasionally throws a surprise punch.

[h3]Conclusion:[/h3]

Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is a tactical masterpiece that balances realism with a touch of strategic absurdity. Whether you're orchestrating intricate maneuvers or chuckling at soldiers defying physics, it's a battlefield ballet that keeps you engaged.

[quote=][i]In the echoing words of a radio operator, "We need artillery support, over!" Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is not just a plea for artillery; it's a reminder that in the chaos of war, sometimes you need a pixelated symphony of explosions to turn the tide in your favor.[/i][/quote]

This immensely enjoyable World War II real-time strategy game boasts exceptional mechanics that elevate the gaming experience to new heights. The brilliance of this game shines through every aspect of its design and execution.

Ladies and gentlemen, hold onto your helmets because Men of War Assault Squad 2 is here to take you on a rollercoaster ride through the most explosive, chaotic, and absurd battlefield you've ever experienced! If you've ever wondered what it's like to be a World War II general in charge of a bunch of troops who seem to think grenades are the answer to every problem, this game will give you the answer. It's like herding cats, but the cats are armed to the teeth and have a strong desire to blow things up. First, let's talk about the graphics. They're like a fine wine that's been aged in a rusty tank. But who needs fancy graphics when you can witness the glorious spectacle of a tank doing an elegant pirouette after hitting a landmine? It's like watching ballet but with more explosions and fewer tutus. The realism in this game is off the charts. Your soldiers will take cover behind anything and everything, including the world's flimsiest wooden fence that somehow provides impenetrable protection from heavy machine gun fire. You'll also learn that the quickest way to disarm a tank is to throw a hand grenade at it. Logic? Who needs it? Now, let's talk about the AI. Your troops will either be brilliant tactical masterminds, taking cover and flanking enemies with precision, or they'll decide to go for a swim in the middle of a firefight. It's like playing Russian roulette with your own army. The best part of Men of War Assault Squad 2 is the physics engine. Tanks flip over, buildings crumble, and soldiers go flying like they're auditioning for a superhero movie. It's a physics-based comedy show that will leave you in stitches. And the multiplayer? It's a battle of wits and explosives. You and your friends can team up to conquer the world or accidentally blow each other to smithereens. It's like playing a game of chess where the chess pieces have rocket launchers. Men of War Assault Squad 2 is a game that will have you laughing, crying, and questioning the laws of physics all at once. It's a delightful romp through World War II where strategy meets slapstick, and where every battle is a chance to witness the most improbable and hilarious moments in gaming history. So, grab your helmet, rally your troops, and get ready for a war unlike any other—one where the only rule is that there are no rules, and where the explosions are always bigger than you expect.

Title: Men of War: Assault Squad 2 - A Tactical Warfare Masterpiece

Men of War: Assault Squad 2, developed by Digitalmindsoft and published by 1C Entertainment, is a tactical real-time strategy game that places players in the heart of intense World War II battles. As a fan of strategic warfare games, I'm excited to share my review of this exceptional title.

Gameplay (4.5/5):
Men of War: Assault Squad 2 excels in delivering a visceral and authentic World War II experience. The game features a robust single-player campaign that spans various theaters of war, from the Eastern Front to the Pacific Theater. It also offers skirmish and multiplayer modes that provide a wealth of replayability.

The core gameplay revolves around commanding a small squad of soldiers or controlling individual units, each with distinct abilities and roles. The level of detail in unit management is remarkable, allowing players to perform tasks such as loading artillery, repairing tanks, or sniping enemy troops. The emphasis on tactics, cover, and resource management makes for deeply engaging and challenging gameplay.

Graphics and Sound (4/5):
Visually, Men of War: Assault Squad 2 presents detailed environments and authentic vehicle models that capture the essence of World War II warfare. The game's physics engine adds a layer of realism, with destructible environments and vehicles responding realistically to damage.

The sound design is impressive, with authentic weapon sounds, explosions, and ambient battlefield noise immersing players in the chaos of war. The orchestral soundtrack complements the action, enhancing the game's atmosphere.

Realism and Authenticity (4.5/5):
One of the game's standout features is its commitment to realism and authenticity. The attention to historical accuracy, from the weaponry to the uniforms, is commendable. The inclusion of realistic ballistics, vehicle mechanics, and destructible terrain adds depth to the gameplay.

The game also embraces asymmetrical warfare, with different factions and units possessing unique strengths and weaknesses. This forces players to adapt their strategies based on the faction they choose and the mission at hand, adding a layer of complexity and depth to the experience.

Community and Modding (5/5):
Men of War: Assault Squad 2 boasts a vibrant modding community that has created a wealth of user-generated content. Players can find a wide array of mods, including new maps, missions, factions, and even total conversions. This extends the game's lifespan significantly and allows players to tailor their experience to their preferences.

Conclusion (4.5/5):
Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is a tactical warfare masterpiece that caters to fans of World War II strategy games. Its focus on realism, attention to detail, and commitment to historical accuracy set it apart in the genre. Whether you're a fan of solo campaigns, challenging skirmishes, or competitive multiplayer battles, the game offers a multifaceted and deeply satisfying gaming experience. It's a testament to the enduring appeal of authentic and engaging real-time strategy warfare.

"Men of War: Assault Squad 2 - A Tactical Triumph for Strategy Enthusiasts"

"Men of War: Assault Squad 2," developed by Digitalmindsoft, is a remarkable real-time strategy game that masterfully combines detailed tactical warfare with an immersive World War II setting. This game stands out as a rewarding experience for strategy enthusiasts and history buffs alike.

Authentic and Immersive World War II Setting (4/5):
"Men of War: Assault Squad 2" plunges players into the heart of World War II with meticulously recreated battlefields, weapons, and vehicles. The attention to historical accuracy is evident in every detail, from the uniforms of soldiers to the authenticity of weaponry. This level of immersion adds depth to the game, making it feel like a true historical reenactment.

Realistic Tactical Gameplay (4/5):
The gameplay is the star of the show, emphasizing tactical realism and strategic depth. The game rewards careful planning and resource management, as players command small squads of soldiers across challenging missions. The ability to control individual soldiers and vehicles allows for precise tactics, and the destructible environments add a layer of realism rarely seen in real-time strategy games.

Variety of Factions and Units (4/5):
With a range of factions, including the Soviet Union, Germany, and the United States, players have the opportunity to experience different perspectives and military doctrines. Each faction offers a unique set of units, adding diversity and replayability to the game. The inclusion of a cooperative multiplayer mode allows friends to tackle missions together, enhancing the teamwork aspect of the game.

Learning Curve (3/5):
While the depth of tactical options in "Men of War: Assault Squad 2" is a strong point, it can also be intimidating for newcomers. The learning curve is steep, and players may find themselves struggling initially to grasp the game's intricacies. However, for those who invest time in mastering its mechanics, the rewards are substantial.

Graphics and Sound (3/5):
The game's graphics and sound design, while serviceable, do not push the boundaries of modern gaming. The visuals are functional, but they won't astound players with cutting-edge graphics. However, the detailed unit animations and destructible environments contribute to the game's authenticity. The audio design, including weapon sounds and voice acting, adds to the immersion.

Community and Modding (5/5):
"Men of War: Assault Squad 2" has a thriving modding community, which significantly extends the game's longevity and content. Players can find an array of user-created missions, units, and maps on the Steam Workshop, enhancing the game's replayability and offering diverse gameplay experiences.

Conclusion:
"Men of War: Assault Squad 2" is a strategic triumph that successfully balances historical authenticity with intricate tactical gameplay. Its attention to detail, realistic combat mechanics, and a vibrant modding community make it a must-play for strategy enthusiasts and fans of World War II history. While the learning curve may pose a challenge for newcomers, the depth and satisfaction of mastering its mechanics are well worth the effort. This game offers a captivating and immersive World War II experience that will keep players engaged for countless hours.

There's a lot to say about this game, and while overall I'd recommend it there are definitely some significant cons to it which I think are worth mentioning. First of all with the pros:
1) The editor is great. You can run tons of simulations with different battles over and over, if you learn some basic editor stuff (like endless armies) you can really do a lot. This is probably the best part of the game for how much you can do with it.
2) The base game missions are fairly fun. Admittedly, they can get quite repetitive between countries, but at least your first few are quite interesting and have some nuance to the strategy involved. 
3) When it works*****, the multiplayer is incredibly fun.
4) Mods. They are incredible, with massive variety allowing you to play different scenarios from the american revolutionary war to warhammer 40k
Now on to the cons, of which there are two major ones I'd like to mention here
1) This is likely something you've seen ad nauseam if you've been reading reviews for this game, but a big con is that bots and skirmish mode are not part of the base game. They require DLC. Again, you've likely already seen this but it's scummy enough of a move that I would feel wrong not mentioning it in a review.
2) And 2 is a very big one. While the multiplayer is very fun, it has some extremely significant weaknesses. In order to outline this, I'll go through a typical session of multiplayer for someone new to the game. So, you're new, you load into the lobby selection you get into a game and -you're kicked- you notice a lot of the lobbies don't even let someone in whose at your level. In fact, most of the lobbies you join (70-80%) kick you. You may spend upwards of 20 minutes just trying to get into a lobby at all that doesn't kick you instantly. On a bad day, it can even take 40 mins or more. If you have bad ping (>100 ms) this is even longer and if your ping is greater than 200 ms, you are unlikely to get into a lobby at all. Let's say you're patient enough (or lucky enough) to find your way into a lobby. After 10 minutes, the slots in the lobby get filled and your host starts up the game. You're enjoying yourself and liking game and it's strategy when all of a sudden, your teammate leaves. Maybe they made a mistake and raged, maybe their connection cut. Either way, you're down a player. And another the moment that your other teammate realizes it. You try to stay in order to play out the game, only to get absolutely squashed flat by the combined power of 3 other people with 50x the number of hours you have in the game. Even in games where your own teammate doesn't leave, often somebody on the enemy team will, which ruins the game just as much. Being conservative, I'd say that about 40% of games have at least one person leave, and often more. Sometimes, you'll get that euphoric experience of playing and winning (or even losing) that perfect game where you coordinated with your team and used strategy and had an overall amazing rts experience, but this is not most games, hell, it isn't even a good number of games. This is the rare minority of games if you are a new player.

Overall, there are many reasons to love this game, but if you're in it for the multiplayer in particular, be prepared for what that entails.

Odd game I would not recommend it at full price. That being said I like it and enjoy the intention despite not having played it very much. 

I have only played a few single player campaign missions (wtf skirmish mode is paywalled? are the devs call center scammers? no they clearly cared too much because they included weird features) and to be completely honest they are super lazy. Basically two of the missions I played were the exact same mission. There is no loving voice acting or really any sort of tutorial so the entire experience could easily be a turnoff for a player, The missions have cruddy unskippable cut-scenes where normally a tank blows up and you are told to go capture the tank, This seems to involve moving to the tank and using a "repair kit item" on the tank, but to be honest one of the tanks I was trying to repair took too long so I just quit and moved to a different mission (did one guy working on the tank slow things down? Should I have found more squads and repair men to repair the tank?). 

This abrasive intro to the game hides some of the bizarre features the game includes. Such as every soldier apparently having a diablo (tetris, dayz, cell based) style inventory that they can use to carry ammo and shells around. Or the fact that each little soldier is their own independent unit that will (so appears to the user) get auto assigned to a squad when selected with other solders or vehicles. One of the really cool features the game has (Direct control of vehicles) is just a feature you have to find by clicking on all the buttons until you find it. All of these features are great for lifeless idiots like myself who would explore them, but really just sort of an annoying waste of time for anyone who's time has value. 

Even as a lifeless idiot I didn't really care enough to see if you could create some bizzare mega inventory by loading up individual soldiers and then combining them into a squad. So while I know the inventory system exists, I don't know how it works. 

Maybe it was me just blindly clicking until there were guys shooting at each other and ending up on a truly pathetic difficulty level but it seemed that the computer opponents in missions were pathetically easy to kill and my own guys would never die if I just kept them in cover. Either way, game appeared super boring because the main challenge seemed to be determining what sort of idiot savant-like brain damage the game devs who made this game (a decade ago it seems?) were coping with. I have read a comment on this game that they attempted simulation over casual enjoyment, I respect the attempt to build simulation but you would think they would have tried to make that evident somehow ("player, please look at these features we included"). 

Maybe I just don't understand the depth of the game, but I don't really want to. If I were even more lifeless than I already I am, I might.
 
I don't regret the purchase because it was a 5 dollar whim. Poor execution, interesting mechanics, sloppy package all together, 1/5 gameplay, 3/5 creativity. 4/10 together. 

Hopefully the game files are easy to rip out of the game, maybe I can score some easy graphics or audio assets out of it. (edit) good news they are all just ".zip" files that have been renamed to ".pak" files. dog/03.wav is adorable.

Soldiers, Sailors, and Airmen of the Allied Expeditionary Force!

You are about to embark upon the Great Crusade, toward which we have striven these many months. The eyes of the world are upon you. The hope and prayers of liberty-loving people everywhere march with you. In company with our brave Allies and brothers-in-arms on other Fronts, you will bring about the destruction of the German war machine, the elimination of Nazi tyranny over the oppressed peoples of Europe, and security for ourselves in a free world.

Your task will not be an easy one. Your enemy is well trained, well equipped and battle-hardened. He will fight savagely.

But this is the year 1944! Much has happened since the Nazi triumphs of 1940-41. The United Nations have inflicted upon the Germans great defeats, in open battle, man-to-man. Our air offensive has seriously reduced their strength in the air and their capacity to wage war on the ground. Our Home Fronts have given us an overwhelming superiority in weapons and munitions of war, and placed at our disposal great reserves of trained fighting men. The tide has turned! The free men of the world are marching together to Victory!

I have full confidence in your courage, devotion to duty and skill in battle. We will accept nothing less than full Victory!

Good luck! And let us beseech the blessing of Almighty God upon this great and noble undertaking.

A game I've loved for years, it always brings me back even after everything. Even if the game itself can be very challenging, its always worth coming back to.

The devs have tried to recreate the same game in CTA and MoW2, but honestly I really cannot imagine that they can ever top what they did in this game. Its really a perfect mix of everything.

I wont go over the gameplay itself honestly, its just a good RTS game that provides an individual unit management system, and dynamic armor penetration mechanics. Its realistic, but in a way that still maintains a semblance of fun.

The modding scene is mostly active, with the majority of the great mods being made a few years ago, as it goes for older games. My own personal Favorite mod being "WW2" by Renya. It adds a dozen of new factions (that really should have been in the game by default to be honest), without changing the gameplay i love so much.

Overall the game is great, the DLC is useless and only serves to lock content behind a paywall for no reason. 

Do not buy the game normally, always buy this on sale, and in the bundle. If you pay $10 for each DLC, I will personally find you and take all of your money.

Otherwise you will not have all the content the game offers. I Hate DLC based games so much.

MOWAS 2 is an amazing game. We are damn near 10 years since its initial release and it is still a game I regularly play. To my knowledge it is, one of, if not the only RTS of this category. No building barracks to spawn men who you control as a group and have generic HP bar that you can buy upgrades for etc. No running around trying to secure resource so you can build more building etc. Its just raw combat where every soldier has stats, inventory and a name. You can direct control every unit, pick up guns of the enemy, and so much more. 
           The modding community has really shined in this game. Are you bored of ww2? Why not try ww2+ with a realism mod, or maybe you want to play Vietnam? or modern day? fuck do you want to play 40k universe? you can do it with the help of mods on the workshop. 
           I truly cannot recommend this game enough, if you have any inkling of buying it I would strongly suggest doing so.

The game is one of the best RTS's to exist, they made sure that every little detail is here.

If youre into games like company of heroes, arma 3, or the total war franchise then this is for you. You've got the choice of the campaign where you play as a range of countries during ww2 in different parts of the world carrying out missions where you can use the troops available to you to smash the opposing force. You can make use of the multiplayer which is the same as the campaign but instead of fighting the ai you fight other players.  Or you can go into the Editor where you have the freedom to make your own maps or use other pre made maps and form your own battles and scripts as you see fit, although it does take a while to work out how to use fully. There are an abundance of mods as well to use alongside this game, most notably the star wars mod which as oyu might already be able to tell, turns the game into star wars and give you the use of everything star wars based in the editor. Highly recommended for those with hours to pour into games who also enjoy a more solo playing style.

Men of War is a war RTS game that delivers an immersive and realistic war experience. Its main advantage lies in the accuracy of details in the tactical and strategic aspects of war. The game allows players to control each unit individually, providing a high degree of control in battle. In addition, the wide variety of units and weapons provides great tactical freedom. However, Men of War's weakness lies in its high difficulty level and steep learning curve, making it not so friendly to new players. Also, the sometimes unresponsive or less intelligent AI can detract from the gaming experience.

The best one in the Men of War franchise, and the one still being played and modded since 2016 for a damn good reason. Whenever another WW2 RTS that tries to be detailed and realistic comes out, this is the one it will get compared to.

If you are looking for a realistic and challenging WW2 strategy game, Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is a great choice. You can play solo or co-op campaigns, skirmishes and missions, or compete online with other players. You can control every unit directly or command large armies from above. You can choose from many different factions, vehicles, weapons and maps.

The game is not flawless, though. It has some bugs, crashes and performance issues. The graphics are outdated and the interface is clunky. The game can be very hard and frustrating, especially for newbies. The AI can be either too dumb or too smart, depending on the difficulty. 

But I still love this game. I have spent 100 hours playing it and I still enjoy it. The single player mode is awesome and a great time waster. The game has a lot of depth and variety and it never gets old. I love commanding my troops and seeing them do what I want. The game also has a lot of mods and custom maps that add more content and fun.

So if you are into realistic and challenging WW2 strategy games, you should give Men of War: Assault Squad 2 a try. It is not for everyone, but if you can handle its flaws and learn its mechanics, you will have a blast with it. It is a good game in the genre and it has a lot of replay value. If you can get it whilst it's on sale. that's even better. 

I rate it 8/10.
Fun and enjoyable if your a history or gun nerd like myself. easy to figure out too.

Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is an incredible strategy game that challenges players to command their armies on the battlefield in intense combat scenarios. The game features stunning graphics, realistic physics, and a variety of playable factions each with their own unique strengths and weaknesses.

One of the most impressive aspects of the game is the level of detail put into the gameplay mechanics. Players have full control over their units, from choosing which weapons to use to determining their exact position on the battlefield. This level of control allows for a highly strategic experience where players must carefully plan out their tactics in order to achieve victory.

The game also has a fantastic variety of modes, including skirmish, multiplayer, and cooperative play. Each mode offers a unique and engaging experience that will keep players coming back for more.

Perhaps the most impressive aspect of Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is the attention to historical accuracy. The game takes place during World War II and features accurate models of tanks, planes, and other vehicles used during the conflict. Additionally, the game features historically accurate environments, allowing players to immerse themselves in the era and feel as if they are part of the action.

Overall, Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is an outstanding game that blends intense strategy gameplay with historical accuracy and stunning visuals. It is a must-play for anyone who loves strategy games or World War II history.

I have been playing MOW AS since 2011, and MOW AS2 since 2014, and I still hold this game as the best RTS game of all times.
It is tactical, challenging, the AI is one of the best AI I have ever seen in a strategy game, and above all - It's fun.
It does not feel repetitive even after more than 10 years.

Although, the lack of new content is felt as you run into the same missions you've been playing for the last 10 years, and the lack of motivation for the community to come up with new content in the Workshop is also making this game decline unfortunately. 

But none the less, this game will forever stay my favorite RTS game of all time, even long after I will stop playing it.

This is my favorite game of all time. Better than Company of Heroes in my opinion. This game represents a good portion of my childhood. I watched YouTubers like Diplexheated play this game religiously until I was able to acquire a laptop. terrible platform, I could barely run the game on the lowest graphic settings at a tolerable frame rate but I still did it. The creativity that the MOW AS 2 community had when it came to mods and designing mission in the gem editor is comparable to next to no other video game franchise. Although I know RTS is sort of a niche genre of the video game industry it will always be my favorite. 

There are very reasonable complaints people have with the game, especially with the dev team and poor communication that is certainly valid. The disgusting amount of greed related to putting AI skirmishes behind a pay wall is something I was not able to afford and because of that never bought it. I pray the devs learned their lesson with the release of MOW 2. I am very excited to see the future. CTA - GOH: Ostfront is a good example of what was able to come from this community.A game that is not without its flaws, but still phenomenal in my opinion. 

No game is perfect and that is not an excuse for the devs and I understand I am looking through a rose colored lens. I still believe the game is worth a buy to this day.

Anything past Assault Squad 2, is just archaic at this point - it either looks like sh** or doesn't play too well, games like the OG Man of War, Faces of War, Assault Squad 1, etc.

Unfortunately, Assault Squad 2 is not getting any younger by the day lol, while the game is highly moddable, its 32-bit nature keeps it from being TOO modding friendly, as most workshop mods push the engine to the limit, and it sh**s itself when doing anything too intense.

While we do have more modern alternatives running on 64-bit upgraded engine, as say Call to Arms or Gates of Hell, those games just don't have the RIGHT amount of fun on them.
You see, Assault Squad 2 got a lot on the table, the table may be weak, but it's defintely got a lot on its plate - from the vanilla basegame, you can pick whatever major faction you want: germans, japanese, americans, british. Then you can either play the Skirmish maps, which is like a connquer the map mode, as you unlock more powerful units the farther you go, or play matches against the AI (or jump into MP, as well).
On the maps, you have lots of variety: you have french towns, russian villages, industrial complexes etc. Snowy maps, desert maps etc. Something both CtA and GoH lacks, as their maps are rather dull.

And while the graphics may be a lilttle bit dated, the gameplay is both realisticaly complex and smoothly arcadeish - something that the modern alternative, Gates of Hell, unfortunately craves into a more realistic experience, and such, sometimes matches just aren't as fun as AS2.

The base game has alright missions, some are copy and pasted just with different factions and some tend to be really annoying to complete. You get a good amount of Units to play around with and experiment with. There is some amount of replayability when it comes to the single player missions. But the AI is pretty terrible and outdated. The main thing that makes this game shine is its modding community. There are tons of mods to play around with some being historically accurate or other worldly. The graphics are pretty outdated and for people on lower end computers this game should run pretty good on medium settings. I highly recommend to just play the base missions first and get straight into the mods. They make this game amazing and turn a pretty "alright" game into a "amazing" game.

This right here is a pretty alright WW2 RTS strategy game. But unlike other previous Men of War games THE MULTIPLAYER WORKS!!!!..... kinda. And the single player isn't half bad either. It also has a DLC for all the missions from the original Men of War game. (Also runs surprisingly well on the Steam Deck)

 Although the single player missions do at times become repetitive as the map layouts and objectives are usually the same. And the exact same missions from Assault Squad 1 with a shinny coat of paint. However it does come with a handful of the AS1 dlc missions free of charge so that's something. Can even play them online in CO-OP. 

The actual game mechanics are janky but mostly adequate. Vehicles sometimes take less than desirable paths to reach objectives and sometimes there's a brief delay between you ordering your units to do things and them actually doing things. But overall nothing to major. 

All the faction unit diversity is cool. Each of the factions have their own historically accurate Tanks, APCs, infantry squads, artillery and even a few special units with no comparable adversary. For example the UK can call in ANZACs, The Americans have a flamethrower tank, Soviets have penal battalions, etc. It's just super cool how each faction has 5-7 unique infantry squads with skins, weapons and in some cases anti tank equipment. The amount of battles featuring the best of the best or the worst of the worst for these factions leads to some intense gun fights. 

It makes combined Arms warfare fun. Tell your conscripts to get on your tanks, mass a large force of multiple tanks, self Propelled guns, APCs and armored cars, then send  them to a fortified objective and see if you planned well enough to take it. 

Some factions are more "OP" than others but the categories of squads, tanks, and guns all make it balanced. Or as balanced as a war can be. The Soviets might have have the most armored heavy tanks but if its under multiple artillery fire from any of the larger Japanese or German guns they'll explode like any other vehicle. 

Multiplayer - lots of game modes and people are still playing. Going head to head with people that put 1000+ in this game can be a daunting task but, his men will die just as easily as yours. And if you don;t want to do that you can join a 6 v 6 and just try to manage your small front. But you can also do the single player campaign missions on co-op so that's cool too. 

It's a bit more technical than company of Heros, also a lot deeper in mechanics. 

80/100

Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is an outstanding real-time strategy game that has a passionate and active modding community. The game's modding tools allow players to create and share their own content, including new maps, units, and game modes. This level of support for modding has resulted in a thriving community that continues to create new and exciting content for the game.

However, like any game, Men of War: Assault Squad 2 does have some bugs that can impact the gameplay experience. Some players have reported issues with AI pathfinding, which can lead to units getting stuck or behaving unpredictably. There have also been reports of occasional crashes and other technical issues.

Despite these bugs, Men of War: Assault Squad 2 remains an excellent real-time strategy game that offers a rich and immersive experience for players. With its attention to detail, challenging mechanics, and extensive multiplayer mode, it is sure to provide hours of entertainment for both casual and hardcore players alike. The thriving modding community adds even more value to the game and ensures that players will have access to new content for years to come.

[h1] An Awesome Realistic World War II Real Time Strategy Game [/h1]
This game is one of my favorite RTS games out there. The awesome modability mixed with a highly replayable and a quite fun gameplay turns this game into what most people on the RTS community calls it one of the best World War II RTS games out there if not the best World War II RTS game ever made.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1] 
If you're familiar with other Men of War games then this game is pretty much the same but if you're not, The game is basically a more realistic version of Company of Heroes 2 with a plentiful amounts of mods. Although sometimes I get bored by the gameplay pretty easily because the game feels the same as the older men of war games. The same graphics, the same atmosphere, and the same gameplay. I do hope that the upcoming Men of War II would not be a reskin but a whole different game.

[h1] Singleplayer and Multiplayer. [/h1] 
The game is actually still pretty populated for a game that's almost 9 years old by this point. You will find it quite easy to find players to play with. If you're looking to play this game with bots then you're sadly out of luck. The game doesn't have bots to play on skirmish but it does have a campaign. While the campaign isn't as good as Company of Heroes 2's campaign it's still a good addition to the game.

[h1] Modability [/h1] 
This game is like the Garry's Mod of Real Time Strategy games/ There are plenty of mods to try on such as a World War 1 Mod, an American Revolution mod, a Chinese Civil War mod, a Spanish Civil War mod, a Russian Civil War mods and many other awesome mods that you could try on. The game has steam workshop support which makes it very easy if you want to download and install mods for the game. You'll never get bored by the plentiful amounts of amazing mods for this game.

[h1] Suggestion [/h1] 
If you're looking for a decent World War II Real time strategy game to try on then this would actually be a decent choice for you. And on steam sales, most of the time the game's price goes pretty cheap as well. Overall I do highly recommend this game.

Mostly play the game modded in a coop format with close friends, occasional PvP.  Your experience may change with standard online play.

A traditionally WW2-oriented RTS that is rather unique in its formula (at least compared to my experience), more closely resembling tabletop board games with points limits and whatnot.  Gameplay is usually centered more around territory control to win, sans the additional income derived from map nodes from Company of Heroes or Dawn of War, which is the closest comparison I can draw considering standard resource-gathering RTS elements are non-existent here.  If worrying about economy irritates you and you want to get straight into the combat, this is probably a game for you.  Income is a fixed limit, with only some casualty trickle-back, so figuring out your army composition and point effectiveness is necessary so you don't start hemorrhaging resources.

Also akin to CoH is the ability to capture enemy equipment, though I'd argue that it's a much more prevalent in this game and probably one of the things that come to mind when bringing this game up, but there's also veterancy as well.  Unlike CoH, the game is of a less arcade-y nature, fatality rates are much higher here and the game is more brutal when it has the mind to be.  Gone are the days of consistent shell-bouncing (unless you're angling your shot poorly or at a heavily armored location with a lighter than required caliber), taking on a War Thunder-esque armor/penetration model; if you hit a tank in a vulnerable spot with sufficient caliber, expect it to go up in smoke, especially if you hit the engine or ammo rack.  Infantry are also much more squishy and meat-grinders akin to Normandy or Stalingrad can become a common sight unless you take every precaution you can to preserve your manpower.
As a footnote, there's also the option to directly control models, which is also a memorable staple of the game.  Among your other soldiers, now you too can be the tank ace you always wanted to be, which can even turn the tide of an engagement due to more fine controls than the AI. (Not to mention the exploits regarding the aiming reticle, figure that one out yourself.)

The game is excellent in my opinion, though the GEM engine is a bit janky and sometimes the AI-controlled units do questionable things unless you're babysitting them constantly, but what you're getting out of this game I think is well worth it if you can work around this.  Additionally, the workshop supports a wide variety of mods, ranging from; more modern conflicts, a wider array of WW2 factions, earlier conflicts as far back as musket and shot, and fictional universes including but not limited to Star Wars and Warhammer 40k.  There's a lot here for you, and I would've probably paid full price had I not dealt with the earlier two renditions, which more or less was buying the same game over and over with more tinkering done to the engine and mechanics added.
My only outstanding issue with this game is with the Airborne DLC.  Paying for skirmish AI outside of prebuilt missions and whatnot is ridiculous.  Even with as much of a micro-transaction nightmare as Company of Heroes 2 was, it didn't put a paywall on bots outside of the campaign.

This game is very comparable to Company of Heroes 2. In reviewing that game I compared it to Avalon Hill's original Squad Leader and its best PC gaming inheritor, the Combat Mission series. In that regard, Company of Heroes is very playable with decent AI, but maybe not as realistic in physics and combat resolution as Combat Mission. MoW: Assault Squad 2 is similarly playable, has more realistic physics and combat resolution, but requires almost mind-numbing amounts of micro-management to travel or attack in any kind of formation. Nothing here even resembles bounding in attack move for a platoon. To be fair, that is true with multiple platoons in CoH, but it seems even harder here with even a single platoon, requiring moving individual soldiers like some FPS game! It also has some bugs that I think come with its age, e.g., units getting stuck forever in buildings or being unable to find a path around a rock. That said, it seems to have many more challenging single-player scenarios to choose from with a superb variety of unit types and countries available for less than the cost of CoH2. It's also much easier to get to using some advanced heavy armor in these scenarios than comparable CoH ToW scenarios, other than maybe the limited campaigns. Now for the challenge to both (MoW and CoH) of these platforms: I'd love to see future campaign modes where we can use some better strategic maneuvering on a divisional-level map and then drilling down to the tactical combat. CoH2 introduced that, but it felt too simplistic and more like playing a really weak version of Axis and Allies than a good old AH or Strategy and Tactics game.

Okay so, not gonna say anything on SP and MP because to be frank I never played multiplayer (I think) and the single player that I played for maybe 2 out of the 1,300 and counting hours sucked compared to the to first Men of War. Okay now the real reason to buy, BUY THIS FOR MODS. I can not make it more simple, I have put in hours with modern armies and creating scenarios like why not make America and Russia be against Germany a third time right?, but modern! Or why not download the awesome Galaxy at War Star Wars mod and send an army of droids to take over Naboo or maybe stop the rebellion, OR OR have clones vs storm troopers?! Maybe you are a fan of Killzone, mod for that, Gears of War? mod for that now (still needs a lot of work), Want to revisit Vietnam? Mod, Shoot maybe you like american civil war history or muskets, mod (I think its on the civil war). I don't recall a Halo one, but I know Call to Arms has one, the point being, mods are where this game shines. Here is a popular example, think of how Fallout 4 and Skyrim are just so much better with mods, THAT IS THIS HERE. Maybe wait for a sale to be honest, because you can snag this for around $12 sometimes and I don't believe you need the dlcs to enjoy mods.

ALSO!! side note: You can also check the workshop out or Moddb to see for yourself, some mods are bare and haven't been updated, some mods haven't been updated but are close enough to be considered "done" or "good enough", with some still being worked on, others "TBD" but who knows where in oblivion they fell. They do cause crashes here and there, which can be annoying, Just trust me though when I say the mods are where it is at making this game worth it.

Do you know what pain is?

RobZ Realism mod. 
I will not lie if I open all the cards in front of you at once: this is not even a review of this game. No, it's not. 
This will be a little story about this amazing mod and how it made a martyr out of me.

The installation was not long. I quickly turned on the game and drove the first match with bots. 
And it seemed to me that this was the best thing that happened to Men of War. What delicious sounds. What special effects. Realism. The balance. How many new units. And how tanks began to behave here... mmmmmm... But first impressions, as always, are deceiving. The bots were at an normal level, there were 2 of them. I barely won. But I felt that I had to give it a try something harder.

And I did. 

Three bots on the hardest level. 
I'm smiling like an idiot, because I expect a hard, but victory. And a map with a rather specific relief. In the original MoWAS2 it was just for a snack.
I play for the Germans. And the first infantry battle begins. 
Elite troops ran towards the central point. A bunch of STG44, MG42 saw, and automatic carbines. The elite of the elite. 350 points worth. 
The battle began.  
My idiots hid behind cover... and fell from the delicious headshots of some defective troops for 120 points...
The map is empty from my men. 
I don't understand what happened.
I sent a little weaker infantry, craning my stupid face.
They was not hiding behind cover, but was are already lying down and shooting enemies. Yes, the first rule of the mod - covers here are trivially more dangerous than a bare field.

Okay. Let's go with light vehicles. I took my favorite 222 Sonderkrautzeug with a 20mm cannon, a mobile armored vehicle that scatters infantry in the beginning... 
It was mobile... Now it's a slow piece of shit that runs out of ammo fast...
Btw, I lead it into battle, hide behind a hut and mow down the infantry a little bit. Enemy soldier runs out, fires a AT rifle from 999 km away and tears my 222 to pieces... My face paled.

Here come the tanks. Well, brace yourselves! I'll take a Panzerkampfwagen IV. 75mm gun, good armor. It's beautiful in the original. It goes out on the road... and blows up. Gets blown up by a fucking 37mm Stuart shell. It blows up so that half of the infantry near this tank also goes to the next world...
Seriously, by fucking Stuart?
At these moments, my eye began to twitch slightly, but I still held on, trying to understand what happened.

I decided not to play around and took my favorite Stug III. In the original, this machine of death was an imbalanced - the front armor had a 45-degree slope, so everything that flew into it, calmly ricocheted...
It lived here for 10 minutes... against a fucking Sherman 76mm... got its adamantium forehead armor...
I started to have a lot of questions. 
Infantry are worthless here. Armored vehicles are canned goods. Artillery is a slow shit with 3-15 rounds. Tanks are slow and cardboard shit. How am I supposed to play with all that against a ton of Shermans and Sluggers with 90mm tubes?
 How about something heavier?
Ok, I've saved up for a Tiger Veteran.   
Here comes the American Slugger. 
My Tiger fired. Misses.
Slugger in that moment turns his turret around.
Shot fired again. A ricochet. Bad luck again.
Slugger shots and smashed the tracks of the Tiger and tore to pieces 2 tankmen inside.
I shot again. It's a hit. But someone in there still alive.
Slugger fired a shot and the Tiger blew to pieces...

I got more and more questions, and I tore out most of the hair on my ass.

I saved up points for the KingTiger, the most unbalanced tank in the game. I'm laughing hysterically. Its litterally  a fucking Battlestar Galactica, a fucking Death Star of this game.
I see Sherman on the right. 
Targeting. The turret takes a very, very long time to turn.
Sherman stopped at a distance sufficient for a shot.
The tiger turret is still spinning.
Sherman is turning his turret.
My tiger's still got his fucking turret spinning.
Sherman's fucking up. Tears up a couple of tankmen inside, and cuts the Tiger through like plywood.
My turret's still fucking spinning. 
Sherman fires, and my King Cardboard Tiger gets ripped to shreds. Literally. Something happens that can never happen in the original - the tower flies into space, everything else turns into burning scrap metal.

And this - in all my matches. 

I played with real people and sat around godlessly because of spam Shermans. And they dont give a shit on my Tigers. Flamethrowers. My infantry, 88mm Flak. None of them gave a shit. It was like they ignored me, didn't even notice me. 
I spent thousands of points, used the terrain, but the enemy was open to fuck - he was firing cheap shermans in the forehead and tearing my heavy tanks to pieces.

What had worked before went to hell.

At one point.
I played with bots for the Japanese. Infantry pure nation with sucker tanks. I held my own against 3 tough US. 
I took a line of defense, put a bunch of artillery, infantry and tank fighters. 
And the moment came when the points stopped coming. 
I smiled. Yeah, I can't call in reinforcements, but neither can the enemy. I've got the Mannerheim fucking Line up the hill here, and this AI idiot's got nothing. 

...


Three waves.  I withstood 3 waves with my bare feet without reinforcements... Each of 5-8 tanks and up to a hundred infantry...
I somehow survived by a miracle. 
Wiping sweat from my ass, I still tried to understand what was happening. The game shouldn't work like that. The computer is spending points that it shouldn't have. It sends tanks and people in crazy numbers that shouldn't be there. What the hell? 

Gametime - 90 minutes
I'm at zero. People are out of ammo, tanks have only armor-piercing shells, guns are empty. 
It's only a matter of time
and the infantry spots 12 tanks with a few hundred men coming out 
and just fucking demolish my entire line...

It's hard to say where the smoke from my ass was visible. I've never seen such a brutal rape before. It was so unbalanced, it fucked me up. The computer had infinite points.

I wanna banged the keyboard a couple of times, which I hadn't done in 10 years for sure. Nothing has pissed me off like that for a long time. It's hard to piss me off in general, but this mod did it.

But I was drawn to continue to turn on this piece of crap and play on. And burn with it. I don't know what it is.
And then it hit me.
This game is a friendzone. Yes, you read that right. When she writes you that "you are a good friend" and "that I would like to have a boyfriend like you", but your head just explodes "fuck, what her are talking about? How i need to understand that? Why its so painful?". But you calm down when she writes you "Lets go to the park" in next 5 hours and so on for eternity. You are a hostage of this very bad relationships. Like with this game.
It's a mod in which you are always in pain. It has you always and everywhere, your every action is wood in your ass stove. It's masochism in its purest form. 
Before every match, i want call to parents and tell them "Mom, dad, i love you, farewell" as if it were my last hour of life.
This mod is a message from satan that we are unwanted God childrens on this Earth.
It slowly drives you crazy. One blown up KingTiger and you remember horrible moments from your life, how you may have been beaten or humiliated. All your infantry fell - and you laugh through tears at the screen. Three Yadpanters were blown up in a minute - and you lie in the fetal position for several hours, not answering calls and messages. If this game were a person, it would be a burly bearded man pissing on you while you cry and call for your mommy.
I don't know what I did to deserve to play this mod. Maybe for some sins. Maybe I didn't give a homeless man a penny. I didn't buy some child an ice cream. 
So if you have lost s&m whip at home, buy and download it
If you hate yourself - download it.
Recommend it to your enemies.

Anyway
Do you know what pain is?

9/10 - Excellent addition to the franchise.  No game is better at this genre.

MoW is a great franchise.  It's similar to the Company of Heroes franchise, but it's significantly better.  The squad-based mechanics are far superior.  You can get by playing on a macro/squad-level scale most of the time, but there's also the capability to get down to micromanaging an individual soldier down to aiming for him.  The mix of macro/micro is great in my opinion.  I find myself occasionally directly controlling a specific solider, gun, or tank for some reasons, but it NEVER feels tedious.  It's not often, it makes it feel more realistic, and it adds a different feel to occasionally directly do something.  Maps are great, missions are great, nothing to complain about.

Short and simple review.

PROS:

- Is pretty good with mods.
- Fun gameplay
- Lots of map variety
- Decent AI

CONS:

- 32 bit engine leads to quite a few out-of-memory related crashes
- Poor FPS most times unless it's 1v1/2v2.
- Dated graphics
funny mods make funny game into funny warhammer 40k game
mod community makes it worth it~ single player is trash but a good vessel to put your ideas

Probably the best Men of War ever made (debatable now)

---( Playerbase )---
It's a causal RTS game, nothing really different from the genre other then independet unit control. It's a bit micro heavy at times but nothing hard do to. 

---( Graphics/Animation )---
Due to the game being old and and RTS graphics aren't good at all. From long range it looks a lot better than zoomed in. Mods can improve but since the engine is old it has limitations. 

---( Price )---
Worth the price, it's still around 25£ even though it's an old game but the experiance and playstyle is worth it, compared to COH it's more realistic and micro heavy and compared to bigger battles like Steel Division or Wargame it's a more zoomed in direct battle for you to control. 

---( Requirements )---
Medium requirements since graphics are old and pretty bad, but can be CPU heavy and slow down in larger battles that involves a lot of units. This can be fixed by lowering view range or in mp lower the amounts of units each side can use at once. 

---( Difficulty )---
The vanilla Campaign is easy/medium since the vanilla infantry can tank 20 rounds without dying so you can easily win the assault missions by rushing infantry into MGs or using flamethrowers in the open since it takes a long ass time to kill them with small arms fire. Explosives are also nurfed and doesn't really cause max damage. All damage in vanilla is nurfed and super low. 

Modded Campaigns are in comparison much harder and generally better. Damage and weapons actually does realistic damage in most of these mods. Normal infantry are feel weak in low numbers and you are forced to actually use a larger amount of units to assault a position. Especially in Robz, which you can use in the vanilla campaign. Robz makes the campaign harder and more fun, enemy artillery and MG fire is deadly effective with longer range and is an actually problem you need to take care of. 

---( Grind )---
None

---( Story )---
Campaign is based on different battles and theaters in the war, there's no coherent story. Campaign is fun and the different sections in each campaign mission act as sort of a mini story which is enjoyable. The DLC campaigns are in contrast to the vanilla campaigns actually a coherent story in chronological order. The story is not the best in these neither but it's a fun playstyle that you have to use compared to mp games.

---( Bugs )---
There's a few bugs, mostly old ones that the devs didn't have time or cared to fix. These are really rare in vanilla because of them are funny and not game breaking in any way. When Playing with mods it's another story. When using bigger conversion mods like WH40k you can cause the game to crash due to new models that doesn't like the old engine that MOWAS2 use. Game crashes caused by explosions are more common when using mods and usually happens when you are zoomed into the thing exploding. 

---( Game Time )---
Certain Campaign defense/ hold the line missions demand you to hold the line for upwards of 40-50 minutes which can be a bit boring while assault missions depends more on the player and the effectiveness you have at taking out the enemy capture points until you reach the final command victory point

---( Enjoyment )---
Consistently fun in both multiplayer and campaign. The defense campaign can as I said earlier be a bit boring due to the length. Mods are really the thing that keeps this game alive. Robz and other conversion mods are really amazing and a lot of fun. They add everything from new units, factions, mechanics and more. 

---( Final Score )---
9/10

This is your game if you seek an engaging tactical WW2 strategy game and are fond of extreme micromanaging.
The fact that you can essentailly set your units to automatically move, cover and attack and the AI that isn't too shoddy make it very easy to learn.
The fact that each and every soldier and vehicle has an inventory with items to use, tanks can be repaired not by a health bar filling up but actual parts being repaired (unless completely destroyed, disabling the function of that part like losing a track making the tank unable to move effectively) and that you can even directly control individual units make it extremely hard to master.
The steep learning curve is quite fun and for a game this old it held up stunningly in terms of visual quality.

Just beware if you're an achievement hunter: The game has *lots* of them and require you to play through all campaigns on the highest difficulty.. which in this game really is difficult.
