I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 42 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my faction and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This game was some of the most fun I've ever had in a strategy game. I just got off a game where Big Tony was the Soviet Union attacking whilst me and my other friend had to defend our position as Germany and Japan. For the next 20 minutes, I proceeded to use my 88mm Flak Artillery Gun to decimate 35 of Big Tony's tanks as he simmered in rage the whole time. Throughout the game I also sent miniature remote controlled vehicles packed with 100 tons of explosives to detonate under the tanks causing chain reactions that destroyed multiple tanks at a time. In fact, that reminds me of the previous game where I used 1 AA gun in the back of the truck to drive around to where Big Tony's artillery was positioned and proceeded to absolutely genocide all of his artillery and supply trucks.

Overall, 10/10 would farm Big Tony again.

Has a warhammer 40k mod (found here https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1589620185) that allows you to see the full glory and destruction of the 40k universe on a physics based engine.

See a bunch of guardsmen? Watch them all blow up and explode from plasma and las fire in a realistic way

It is the perfect replacement for the original Dawn of War

Other mods include but are not limited to:
America Born in Fire (a revolutionary war-american civil war mod muskets and all)
Vietnam '65 (a mod to make the game take place in vietnam)
Star Wars (Clones v Droids)

Not to mention just the base game is a very fun WW2 sim, theres something special about an RTS that runs on physics and not dice rolls.

Meaning: When you run a group of men infront of a machine gun they get mowed down realistically as opposed to say Company of Heroes which runs on dice rolls not physical bullets 

In all, pretty great RTS

Undoubtedly a fun game for anyone. Take control of your boys and fight, only to realize that humans are pretty fragile and so are their creations, but you know what? There's a ton of both and hey the war ain't going to win itself.

However what I'm writing this for is actually the most genius thing this game (And to an extent all MOW titles) has is the editor. I love the editor and I've been using it ever since I had the original Assault Squad. Ah those were the days, I'd set up battles with endless generators that would just create more and more soldiers and tanks and whatever else I added in and just watched that for hours, all while listening to Karl Pilkington or SOAD.

I can just picture it, all the bullets and shells flying to and fro blasting every living thing to bits and blowing up vehicles. Then I'd jump in and run someone up to blow up some MG or tank only for him to die and I'd get another man and do it until I finally got the target. All while hearing something like, "I've always wanted to kick a duck up the arse." followed by some hearty laughter.

And to think that was where my creative side really started to grow. 10/10 and as a last note I'd like to thank Prince of Macedon who played it and my Mother for getting it for me after I asked for it.

Amazing game but it needs some attention, there are some bugs and the DLC's don't really give enough content, if your thinking of buying the game or DLC's for it wait for sale since everything is WAY cheaper.

Pros
-The game has good graphics for it's age and type of game.
-Sounds are decent (not delayed, not static but basic) 
-The unit control it pretty good and is rarely frustrating. 
-Has both multiplayer and single, single has a good amount of content but no story behind it unless you buy the ost DLC.
-Mods can add quite a bit of content but can also not work at all.
-Editor mode is fun if you know what your doing and just wanna f around but its quite hard to make units do what you want them to do (when your not controlling them)
-Easy to learn

Cons
-Bugs (sometimes bugs will appear not that often but they tend to be fixable but annoying af.
-When actually manually controlling units it can be tedious for some but after a bit of practice its OK.
- Dead player base - not a lot of people playing especially on Aussie servers but there is enough to play some multiplayer games (If your going to play this game for multiplayer only don't buy)

Anyway i'm still giving this game a 9/10 rating since it is easy to learn and is quite realistic.

This is a game of test. Whether it be testing your tactical ability, patience, will, PC, sanity, or a test of your time. 2,000 hours and I can say I like the game a lot with minor exceptions. I dislike "Stealth" missions, DLC required for bots, how early The Soviet Union gets KV-1s, tanks getting stuck, A.I. firing H.E. at a tank, and how the multiplayer is soul crushing/frustrating. If you play with friends, Make sure they like the game as much as you do or else you'll play alone or rarely, plus, I'd recommend you either have a good relationship with them or play in a way that isn't competitive, unless that's what you want. Mods make it so you can play anyway you want, with or without friends! Only like defense? Download a mission or two. Want to change how the game works? There are many "Overhauls"/Reworks of many mechanics. Plus you can always make and add your own items to the workshop. Overall I love the game, even if it's a glitch ridden dumpster-fire that crashes, it keeps me warm.

The scope of the classic real-time strategy, tactics and micromanagement of the wargame, the ability to directly control any unit - all this is the basis of the gameplay "Behind Enemy Lines: Assault 2". To some, the game will seem similar to Relic Entertainment products, others will remember Blitzkrieg, and still others will find it more similar to previous episodes of Behind Enemy Lines.
However, taking the best from three games, "Storm 2" managed not to get lost against the background of eminent relatives and formed its own style.

Great game, the best WWII RTS.
A very Toxic community tho, here's just 4 reasons why..
1. If you're starting out and low rank you will get kicked from every lobby, if you are experienced with high rank you will get kicked from every 2nd lobby, if your ping is over 100ms you get kicked from every lobby in between (even tho the game won't lag until around 350ms+).
2. Join a match, 3 vs 3 for example, a team mate loses a tank and then quits, the other team mate decides to quit also, you're left alone playing 3 vs 1, (2a). the opposing team ask you to please stay, you stay and lose and then get told by winning team that you are a worthless human being and how they are much smarter, stronger, better looking, richer and generally better than you in life because they beat you 3, 4 or even 5 vs 1..Happens quite often if you allow it by staying.
3. New players may join a match with others who have similar rank and similar amount of games, quickly you learn they are using Steam Family Sharing and have created a 2nd (Smurf) account and they have played on their first account more than 5000 or even 7000 games compared to what their rank states as 100 games played.
4. Playing Combat mode and everyone spams artillery and rockets and then the losing team quit early and (go back to point 2a. of review).
Other than these type of things, it's great fun for the entire family.

one of the best real time tactical / strategy games. It is almost 2 decades old (considering the first "behind the enemy lines / faces of war" game, but still one of the unique games with great physics, letting you to destroy almost every object on the map, great features like manual steering of the vehicles and soldiers and vast variety of tanks, cars, weapons, etc. Besides it does not discriminate any country, represented in the games, giving you an equal opportunity to have all types of missions for every nation.

My review used to be negative for reasons of really sh*tty netcode and performance restrictions, but after the developers of this game released Gates of Hell, which in its current state [strike]is a sham[/strike] isn't really an improvement over this game, MOW:AS2 in comparison is just far more enjoyable still, which is sad. So if you are deciding whether to play MOW:AS2 or Gates of Hell, just wait until MOW:II and then see which is more worthwhile.

The netcode is still pretty bad, so multiplayer games will run as fast as the slowest player's PC performance and internet connection. One guy's PC or internet is sh*t and the whole lobby will lag. But if you play with friends this isn't that big of a problem as you can have better control over who makes up your lobby.

ong the army should let me become a general

I think that this game's graphics are a little outdated for 2022, but otherwise it's still and excellent game and allows me to really think strategically and what-not. I think a new MOW game where you can essentially become a general and decide where to send troops and fight + control single battles like now would make the game super broad and easier to focus on. Also, I think basing the campaigns off of real people like Alexander Patch, Yamashita, etc. unkown/famous generals and making an effort to actually make the campaigns different (all of the levels in every campaign are just the same but reskinned) that wold be cool. Lastly, for the developers, play a game like Easytech's European War 7 (I really like their games btw) and take notes on the way they dealt with online play. An even BETTER way of doing online play would be like in MMOs, where maybe 'generals(the player)' could be paired with other generals and whoever wins, that counts toward their nation's winning chances, and some system where a certain players can become high command officers and tell other officers where to go, like match-making but done by players. Alright, I'll admit, I really like to imagine. I wonder what other cool stuff could be added to boldly revolutionize this game!

MOWAS2 allows me to basically do the same thing and watch/control the battle of my choice.  Great game and a fantastic mod community

One of the best RTS's of all time. The level of detail is amazing. Say you have a group of 8 men, you can break off 2 of them into their own squad. Each man is his own unit with his own ammo, bandages, grenades... the possibilities of unique situations are endless.

As for the engine. It is good for what it is. It isn't insanely good but in terms of what it needs to do, it does it quite well.

This is one of the best games to ever come out in my humble opinion and I am too excited for the next installment of the series which should be coming out soon!

1. #Valour mod: For me the best mod there is. You have many factions, very complete roster and just an amazing mod to play with friends or against AI.

2. Red Rising 3.4: Still new and many minor bugs but I love the idea. The only reason its not number 1 is because of the bugs and weapon and unit variety... other than that, great mod and the visuals are amazing! Cant wait for this mod to be 100%!

3. Deaths Realism: Very similar to Valour, with less units but death animations are really something else and its worth a try.

I have only had this game for a short time but I feel like my measly 4 hours at the time of writing was meaningful enough to form a review of the game. It's probably going to be very long so there's a TL:DR at the bottom.
This is a great game overall. If you like strategy games and games where you're in command of x amount of people, this is one I recommend. It's repetitive enough to feel similar but never gets stale. The campaign missions vary in difficulty and even in style.
However, there is one caveat to this. While it's rewarding enough to keep you engaged, the battles have a very steep difficulty curve and there are controls which are hidden from your view at first sight until you dig deeper. Some of these like double-right clicking to make your soldiers run/vs walk are important to the gameplay and a lot of them don't get explained by the game. It's great that the game assumes you're intelligent enough to figure it out yourself (and you will eventually) but it can make for a frustrating experience.
If, like me, you are new to this type of game, this game will be daunting. I still haven't exited that stage but I assume it's going to happen eventually. Luckily enough for me, this game scratched a particular itch I've had for a long time and it's inexperienced player unfriendliness was nowhere near enough to put me off thus far.

TL:DR, if you're new to this type of game it will take a bit of getting used to. HOWEVER, the gameplay is fun enough even in the noob stages to make for a great time. If you're looking at this game and think that it looks fun, you will probably like it. Try it.

The price is not what I recommend. I recommend that you buy it on sale. (There is a good chance it will not go on sale.)

The campaign is not good, but not bad. It can be fixed by some mods that add custom units and custom missions.

From what I have heard, multiplayer is not very popular during the daytime, but it may be popular at night or on weekends.

Graphics are still good these days; multiple mods allow you to have better effects and a better lighting system.

The units in this game are not historically accurate in uniforms and guns. (But mods can fix that.)

The AI in this game is not very smart. The story page tells us of AI "improvements," but nothing sadly improves in what I see in the game.

Never buy the deluxe edition! It only gives xp and multiplayer stuff that is completely useless, but the xp boost is kind of good. 

Overall, I recommend purchasing it if you enjoy World War II RTS games or are a fan of the Men of War franchise.

If you are buying this game, a little tip for editor missions: Have a team with a convoy of vehicles split up but have the vehicles packed with barbed wire, morphine and medkits, hedgehogs and soldiers, have an officer, radio operator and a ton of riflemen and you can decide the rest. Put the riflemen to work making defenses while the officer and radio operator stay close to eachother to maintain contact with the other units.

A fun, intense game that allows a high degree of control. Did you ever want to be a tank ace? Then take direct control of that Tiger I and start sniping. Want to fire 155mm artillery? Yep, you can do that too. Ever want to suffer and die as one of the rank and file infantry? Sure.

Men of War squads can be directed to move or attack as a group, but you can independently position the squad members how you see fit; you can even make your own with the options you are given. With mods, you can have access to a greater variety of armor, artillery, and infantry, allowing you to specialize as needed for the situation. If you can't afford a tank, then get a tank destroyer; need mobile artillery? Boom, an SPG.

That being said, it's a good game, and graphically aged well... but is notorious for crashes, at least if you play with mods like me. From modern day mods, to ones set in the Napoleonic Wars, there is no lack of content... but it can, and will crash quite often... so be aware of that as you get this game. In spite of that, I recommend it. It is a fun experience, put simply enough.

My MoW:AS2 (Complete Edition) "review" as a solo player + player of the first Assault Squad. 
AKA: Things I like, things I don't in my singleplayer experience. 
FYI: Haven't finished the entire game yet! Still playing through! 

Things I Like:
- They've added new levels! At least, in the complete edition they have. Regular version, I'm unsure. But these new levels are cool and more than welcome. On some levels you can even choose when the assault should take place! 
- It's much easier to resupply things now! Previously, you had to resupply each individual inventory with supply trucks whereas now they have a radius around them in which units will stock up what they need automatically! Thanks for saving us time!
- The new levels add more variety to the game now. Something I didn't like was spending hours on one level, pushing forward through the 3 lines of 3 objectives just to be met by another right after. Now there are plenty of stealth and defence levels which are great!
- Some new units on certain levels you can deploy special units to help out (or in my case, create a more realistic battlefield) Officers for example! 
- They've improved upon the UI and graphics a little, adding more options and effects to the game. That said, my computer can't run this as well as the previous one but that's not saying much. My PC sucks. 
- You have a profile rank. So far, I'm unsure if you actually unlock anything from it, but I do like seeing that I'm earning xp. I think it's mainly for show in the multiplayer but you can earn xp in the singleplayer missions too!
- They've kept in everything I loved in the previous installment. I loved some of the old levels. I love reinforcing positions. I love moving up my line of forces and...well...I love this game too! But...


Things I don't like:
- It's Assault Squad 1, but with a few extra things. I'd expect more from a sequel and so should you! A few new levels...a useless rank system...persisting problems...no massive changes...no redone levels...no multiple looks for all those copy and pasted soldiers...more effort next time. This is just AS1.5...not AS2. Disappointed. 
- Choosing when the assault can take place: This is something I only just recently found and it's becase I went off the level and chose it from the menu. You can't do this with every map, which is fine, but had I have not went back to the menu and clicked on it, I would have completly played through the level/campaign without this feature. 
- Some bonus missions from the last game like the christmas one aren't here...what gives? You already have AS1 in here? Why not it's bonus levels?
- The leveling up is cool but you don't get anything from it. It kind of falls flat if I'm earning xp for nothing and I'm 10 hours in as of writing this and haven't notice anything change other than my level. Multiplayer players may appreciate seeing how experienced I am, but I don't play MP. Useless. Give us alternate uniforms/camos/unlockable units etc.
(The following problems still remain from the last game)
- Being thrust straight into the next mission: Completing this mission took me 3 hours. It says congrats, shows kills/deaths for each side, then gives two options. Continue playing the match or load the next level. NO! Give me something for slaying the opposition! Give me an option to go to the main menu and leave!
- I don't feel rewarded by completing missions as much as I should do: In the last 10 minutes of a possibly hour long level, you can just tell you're gonna win. All you get for that is a window saying congrats, with your losses and theirs and some Steam achievements. If I've killed 3 times as many of their units and destroyed 3 times as many of their vehicles, you'd expect more than that! I think this could be improved upon. Maybe a system of upgrades or unlocks for your faction. Maybe this is where they could add those Officers and shotgunners in. 
- Units STILL being locked to what mission you are on: E.g. There is a mission for the USA where it's more infantry focused, airborne to be specific. They allow you to call in officers but they aren't on every mission. I feel like they where more prevelent than some of these tanks. Imagine having more super heavy tanks than officers on the field. It would be chaos!
- Coming back to play the hardest HEROIC difficulty was a waste of time. Damn things stupidly impossible, 

That said, this game is great..because it's the previous game, which was great...but with more stuff. 
I plan on playing a lot more. 
In the last one, I completed the USA missions and tried some of the Commonwealth and Russian missions too. 
I think I'll end up doing the same here. 

Anyway, if you liked Company of Heroes and maybe wanted more depth and a longer experience, or if you liked Commandos but wanted it on a larger scale, then I can definately recommend this to you! 
If you liked the last game and are ok with playing some old levels again to get to the new ones, then go for it. They're quite fun and different from the last game!
And if you're a fan of the snowy battles in Band of Brothers, I'm currently on a mission with a similar feel!

A surprisingly coherent mix of a very detailed battle simulation and deep, dynamic tactical gameplay. 

I could never really get into rts games due to the need for clunky micromanagement, but this game is simply fantastic. Units have a little freedom, like they go prone under fire, sometimes throw grenades at entrenched enemies or passing vehicles, they jump away from grenades too (auto dodging AoE is something not even relatively gigantic titles like TWW or DOW cared to implement).

My only issue with this game is some weirdness in pathfinding: e.g. sometimes units leave trenches and go around it instead of just walking through it. Climbing over fences just doesn't work 80% of the times and when it does, units climb over in line instead of spreading out.

Apart from that, the game is really solid and very enjoyable (my personal favorite way to scratch that tactical itch we all have from time to time). Take your time to learn all controls, some tactical basics and train with friends against bots before going public multiplayer.

Note: I highly recommend at least one person from your party to have airbourne dlc, which unlocks bots for custom multiplayer matches. Other then that, the workshop is filled with custom missions, units and even total conversions like Vietnam or even Stalker lol, so you don't need all that much dlc content anyway

Also, make sure you play singleplayer on normal at first, hard/heoric is generally only playable with friends if you are new to the game

I started playing this game originally because of the Warhammer 40k modding scene, but boy, the base game is awesome by itself. My friend and I completed the online campaign for all the forces, and it was usually a good time. The game takes a lot of historical battles from World War 2, and pits you as either Axis or Allies. All the major factions are there to play, although I would have liked to have seen others like the Canadians/French played out more.

Battles usually revolve around capturing objectives if you are the attacking force, with tanks/infantry. You will occasionally have artillery and aircraft support, but its not often. Some of the battles were downright beautiful/ albeit chaotic. Infantry scrambling for cover while tanks advance and fire their guns, artillery raining down on enemy positions, and sometimes aircraft dropping their payloads.  Its get just as fun in multiplayer! Playing COOP is also really enjoyable if you can get a friend to play. Some of the battles are so large in scale that they really affect the performance even on high-end machines (probably due to poor optimization).  There are no resources to speak of, no resource gathering. Its all from captured points or just generated if any. 

The modding scene for this game is amazing. There are many different types of mods which are just awesome. Activating mods from the work shop is very simple, as you just subscribe to them and activate in game. There are a few which require a little more tinkering in the main root folder of the game but otherwise it was straightforward. Starwars / valour / robzrealism are a few good ones that I know. There are also many maps for the vanilla game, which can really add a lot of replayability for the game. As of writing this, I have 439 hours. A lot of that was also spent in the game editor. The editor itself is a bit complicated at first. If you have any design and programming backround, its not to difficult to figure out. You can create your own custom maps and scenarios with various timed events via scripting. The scripting engine was not too bad, I was able to create a few different scenarios where the AI would fight each other, and it was really cool watching them try to flank. Of course, you can also program set tasks / waypoints for the units to take, and its really cool to watch the same battle end differently. 

The game itself does not require a high-end expensive computer, as it is a bit dated. But once you start including mods such as high resolution textures / extra effects and additional placeholders for the game , your system will start stuttering if its not at least 2 GB of VRAM. Its rather poorly optimized when all the effects start hitting the screen, and I don't blame the game, but you should limit these in the settings prior to playing (especially in multi-player, where they will affect your ping and performance.) You should aim for a bit higher than the recommended settings, but as it is, I ran it fine on my old PC with a gtx 770 and AMD fx8370.

Realistic? Probably not. But I had a lot of fun with this. 
Game play is a bit dated, but still fun. You start the mission controlling a few units . Some missions are stealth/commando style where reinforcements are almost none. AI can be very difficult to play against. But I would get this on sale. Def a fun game if you are into WW2 . There are also players and modders in the online community that are keeping the game alive.  If you can wait, get it on sale.

I would recommend this game to people, but the largest problem for me is that this game is stuck as a 32 bit game. Large battles will start to cause fps lag and it will eventually become unplayable. With a 64 bit version, the game would run better even if it is slightly better. A big issue with a 32 bit application is also memory limitations. Many have and still experience out of memory errors, this is due to the 4 GB RAM limitation placed due to the game being 32 bits. 64 bits would virtually eliminate that issue given you have the resources. The developers don't seem to have any motivation to make this game 64 bit as their previous argument was it would split the gaming community. The reality is most computers can handle 64 bit programs hence why most video games are 64 bit. This game is frozen in time so unless you want to be limited in what you can do I suggest finding another game like this for now. Also I have both AS-1 and AS-2, both games are generally the same thing with some differences that does not make this game worth nearly $30. If you have AS-1 stick with it, don't bother with this one unless you want to toy around with gem editor (which is the only thing I really use in this game.)

Oh my god the graphics are terrible. The first mission is you literally waiting for 3 minutes while your guys shoot at other guys spawning at the edge of the map and running toward your guys, endlessly.  Then, when you can actually select troop to move, it allows you to select a tank *in the same party*.  Ok, cool, right, normal game.  But then the tank takes its own path and ... **runs over your own troops**.... it ran over my medic.

It's got a tough learning curve, but once you get it, it's really an intricately well built and detailed RTS. Being able to command and actually shoot for any unit in the game is a top down RTS player's dream! The amount of control over each unit is awesome and quite complex. You can physically pick up enemy corpses (as too not alert other enemy soldiers) and examine and LOOT their inventory (swap weapons, ammo, grenades, helmets, etc). Keep up the awesome work!

First off, this game is best described as a simulation RTS. The gameplay is so detailed you can edit individual soldier's inventories and pick up ammo/supplies from fallen friends of foes. Tanks have fuel, and they can get stuck. You can shoot the tracks off a tank, or you can shoot right through it with a Pak anti-tank gun. The realism is really what separates this game from other RTS's, such as Company of Heroes. In COH, it takes about 5-6 shots to kill a single guys at point-blank range. In MOW, it takes 1-2 shots.

However, this game requires CONSTANT micro-management. You cannot send your troops to a position then forget about them. You need to manually put them in prone, crouched, and standing position. You manually must tell them to throw a grenade. With all the mm, it is very hard to manage multiple units.

As a WW2 simulation, this is the closest to reality you can get right now. As an RTS, it is painstakingly tedious to manage every one of your units, it truly is a burden. If you want to truly experience commanding war in a game, this is a great game, But if you want to send about a squad and forget about them, they will die and you will lose. Your units have no AI on their own and can't really do anything for themselves. It is really up to you everything they do.

The micro-management is the worst part about this game, but it's realistic features still make it an amazing RTS that I recommend to hardcore strategy and war game fans.

[h1] An Incorrect Summary of Men of War: Assault Squad II.[/h1] 

[b]So what can you expect?[/b]

[list]
    [*]You're interested in WWII.
    [*]You click buy.
    [*]This is where the fun stops and the war crimes begin. 
[/list]
[list]
    [*]There are two factions, Axis and Allies, just like the real World War II.
    [*]Every individual country has a campaign you can play and they vary in number of war crimes depending on which one you play.
    [*]You think that's it? Too bad you're wrong and there's more.
    [*]Hans gets a flammenwerfer, Johnny gets his shotgun, Sir Nathaniel gets his crumpets and tea, and Japan idk, I don't play weeb faction. 
[/list]
[list]
    [*]There is also multiplayer, which is another word for cancer and long matchmaking times but that's fine.
    [*]The singleplayer is extremely polished and has tons of content. 
    [*]I've played this game for several years now and it never really gets old it's quote fun, especially co-op game modes.
[/list]
[list]
    [*]Unlike other trash games, there are no micro-transactions and it doesn't need the other DLC's to actually be playable. 
    [*][strike]There aren't actually shotguns in the game that I know of.[/strike] Correction: There are. 
    [*]That's about it. Congratulations, you have finished playing a session for the day and committing various war crimes across Europe and Asia, it has been a good day. 
[list]
    [*]This game CANNOT take the place of a girlfriend in your life, it is not an FPS.
    [*]When you put money into this game (aka buying it,) It does not try to do good, IT IS good.
    [*]If you play Axis you will be put on a watch list.
    [*]That's all for today folks!
[/list]

Great game with decent graphics. Classic RTS with "men of war" feel. Sofar, seems campaign is intense..., and it takes balanced push forward..., take your time.

Just noticed, the inventory system has been improved a lot. Now, you only need to select a whole squad and pickup any type of ammo from any type of dead enemy via inventory screen, the ammo, no matter the type, will be distributed to the squad member that most needs it automatically, this really is good news.

You also can pull back your no ammo left squad to air dropped ammo box area (or at the mission start point where there is supplier truck with supply area) to fully re-gain ammo automatically.

How to make a squad: anything you select, anytime you select, becomes a squad or a new squad, no matter it's group of soldiers or mix with tanks, just select it, the relative icon will appear at the left bottom corner, but squad member's number is limited.

This game is fantastic in most ways, and pretty awful in others. It's a game of strategy, though not just any RTS. Men of War: Assault Squad 2 goes into such intense depths that each individual soldier has their own inventory system, as well as their own specialties. The level of micromanagement is so detailed that you can not only loot corpses in case your unit is out of ammo or loses their helmet, but you can also repair wrecked equipment and secure enemy vehicles. From smoke bombs, to molotov cocktails, or even being able to switch artillery shells in a tank depending on the armour class you're up against. Soldiers will sometimes throw enemy grenades back if they think about it, which could make or break the engagement. There are so many little things about this game, that despite the limited map pool, there's quite literally infinite possibilities. I didn't even mention the fact you could stealth through foliage and sneak up on enemies, or being able to destroy entire buildings with the use of a large vehicle. Yes, the entire environment is destructible. If this doesn't sell you on the game, I don't know what will.

However, this is also a problem. Men of War: Assault Squad 2 has so many features, so many details, but the main downside is how terrible the engine is. The game stutters if you aren't using very specific settings, I find that the game doesn't use all of my cores either because of the type of system I have. I have an NVIDIA 2070 super and an AMD Ryzen 5 3600 6-Core Processor, and the game still runs exceptionally awful because it doesn't support Ryzen processors very well. I can adjust the settings to make the game run, however if I want to install a workshop addon, I may as well just play a different game. Be mindful of your system requirements, as due to the age of this game and certain systems being unable to run the game at a decent graphics quality, it's hard for me to recommend this game. I certainly *am* going to recommend this game, but as of 2021, this game still does not have any decent AMD support. It's been 7 years, so you may as well just wait for MoW3. Amazing strategy game, terrible support for my system. 6/10.

At it's base, Men of War Assault Squad 2 is deserving of it's rather mediocre score on Metacritic. It is very difficult to find a decent online match when not playing with a friend. The story mode is rather dull and I quickly lost interest after playing a few of the factions. But with the use of the community workshop, mods can be added to turn the game into what it should have been which is an all out battle simulator. Many fans of this game have created faithful recreations of historical battles while others make the use of other mods to create wacky sci-fi battles. With the use of mods the limit only lies on the user's creativity.
Love the ease of game play and strategy!

where, oh where do i start. I'm going to try ad keep this as balanced as possible.

PRO'S
1.) the game is a decent game, but it gets boring fast (in my opinion.)
2.) has an amazing modding community which makes amazing mods that seriously enhance the gaming experience.
3.) Interesting control scheme which, once accustomed to, makes you 
4.) AI is quite difficult on some of the harder AI levels.
5.) Ability to increase the MP and CP cap is quite flexible and allows for very interesting battles
6:) very indepth in a good way. Able to direct control individual units 
7:) Basic inventory management (if you want to be reallllly inventory clean) but it isn't a necessity
8:) Visuals are okay, not completely terrible but it suits the game well.

Neutral 
Combat could be decent at times although there are alot of problems with AI (see below)
Ai pathing on some maps are very...broken. Some maps have slopes that should be passable and is accepted by the automatic pathing system, so units get stuck until direct controlled away from that specific area. (easy fix, spam mortars and fill the area XD )
Occasionally units ignore commands but its usually easily rectified by getting into the habit of spam clicking to ensure they don't ignore the commands
CON'S
1:) Just before we start with the negatives, the ai. It doesn't come with the game. To be able to have AI, for some reason the developers felt it reasonable to have to buy the airborne DLC just to be able to access the AI. The game should have AI already built in, not have it as a DLC. I feel like that is a seriously unfair money grab. In my opinion
2.) Seriously unstable. I like to play with bots when i play with my mate and we just generally try and have fun. The bots are certainly interesting but we'll cover that next point. Game frequently crashes for unknown reasons. Game frequently crashes for stupid reasons. Usually crashes because the programme is unable to create a dump file for certain files.
3.) AI Bots just spams things. Unfortunately for the game, the AI bots are thick as pigsh*t. The way the AI attempts to beat you is by spamming as many troops as it can at you hoping to do the Russian victory of overpowering with numbers.

Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is a less polished Company of Heroes with a bit more depth. Each battle plays out more like a sandbox where the enemy is consistently pushing back against your every advance. There is no underlying campaign story, just a series of battles that play out roughly the same. Fortunately, the battles are enjoyable and the environments varied. They feel large and at times chaotic as units die easily and keeping them supplied and in good cover is essential. It's disappointing that this great gameplay isn't really supported by much else. With its limited modes and features, the game feels barebones when compared to other RTS titles. The UI is really clunky and unpleasant to work around and a few performance issues plague larger battles. With all that being said, Men of War: Assault Squad 2 corrects many of its predecessor's flaws and is easy to recommend to fans of the series and RTS games. 

+ Deep, thoughtful gameplay
+ Excellent unit details
+ Good use of terrain and land features
+ Sandbox style of play adds to replayability

- Poor unit pathfinding
- Hard to see unit range
- No real story or cohesion to campaign
- Terrible UI
- Performance issues in larger battles
- Lacks polish

Pros: 
Smaller maps than maybe Wargame Red Dragon but with the smaller maps makes the units more “impactful” where a sole AT gun can control the battlefield where you’ll have to have tons on larger maps. 

More direct control of units which some other RTS have but i haven’t found any with this type of control where you can play it kinda like a FPS. (kinda)

There aren’t really any overpowered units except for maybe tanks but a single squad of infantry can take out your expensive tank if you just rush it to an objective which makes the question if you want an artillery piece to destroy an objective or a heavy tank much more “problematic” or harder to decide. 

As stated on the point above with none overpowered units, since you have fewer units on most maps then losing a unit feels more impactful instead of feeling like you dropped your key and on how it’s just a nuisance. 

Guns aren’t accurate, which makes you want to use burst on an MG instead of automatic fire, the inaccuracy is also a downside since especially when you get taken out by an enemy tank since you missed your shot. 

Mods. Base game is fine but the mods take it from like a 5.5 or 6/10 to a 9/10 or even a 10/10 since the mods are also high quality. 


Cons: 
Pretty stupid AI where they do pretty stupid stuff like running out of cover or missing a grenade throw. 

One of the pros I listed earlier with inaccurate fire can be a massive con like when you line up a shot but miss and get killed instead can be massively infuriating especially if you lost an expensive vehicle/unit. 

TL:DR
Greatest RTS i have ever played and maybe one of the greatest games overall mostly from the mods but otherwise great game and i highly recommend it.

This RTS is fundamentally flawed as it does not have a Matchmaker. This results in newbies always getting kicked from the lobby. Because of this it is very hard for a noob to get good. The worst part in my opinion is that you have to pay 10€ to play against bots. In my opinion being able to fight against bots is an essential part of a RTS, it can be used to try things out, or just play a bit more relaxed game. In addition to this the single player missions are rather on the boring side. Still if you are able to ignore all this, the core gameplay is alright. It is pretty fun to take control of you troops and walk/drive them around the Battlefield. But for me the troop selection was a bit weird. It is a cool feature that you are able to select only single soldiers or can split the squad to your liking, but for some unknown reason you can't select several squads.
All in all i would not recommend buying this game. Even though at its core it can be fun, it is not easy reaching this fun and their are better alternatives.

Men of War is a cool RTS game that tries to focus on realism, it mostly does a good job, but it has some very wonky stuff here and there, but it's very bombastic and fun when you're shelling your enemies and blowing buildings apart.

Now, the bad stuff, the game's single-player is basically an afterthought, it has five campaigns that feel mostly similar, since they may take place in different maps, but they're basically the same, the game doesn't feature the classic RTS Skirmish mode(which would be a mock up MP battle against the AI), the only single-player content is the campaign... UNLESS, you purchase the Airborne DLC, which adds bots... Yeah, you gotta buy a DLC to get more single-player bang for your buck, it's absurd.

If nothing of that raises any red flags to you, then sure check the game out, it's a blast if you want a more micro-intensive WWII RTS game.

MoW:AS2 is a fantastic RTS title. It is not perfect. 

       Pros: 

1. This game has spectacular graphics for a game made in 2014. 
2. The movement is great. The AI pathmaking is flawed but functional (some ai seem to be scared of roads but i've only experienced this twice)
3. Gunplay is amazing. Vehicles and Troops are very well balanced, as there are no blatant "metas", meaning there are infinite options, this is complimented by the fantastic direct control which works on every troop.
4. Amazing community with an awesome workshop. 

This is where the pros end.

       Cons:

1. The game is still on 32 bit processing which causes extreme frame loss. Some workshop mods are unplayable without a high-end computer.
2. The developers seemingly have abandoned this game. I believe the last update came out in 2019. The workshop is the only thing keeping this game alive. They most likely have focused there developers on Call to Arms, the latest entry to the series
3. The steam workshop is very flawed. After downloading multiple mods, even if you have matching mods with your friends, a very common error you will come by is 
 "Resource Desynchronization detected. Joining will lead to out of sync error", which denies you access to online lobbies.
4. AI locked behind paywall... In order to use the AI you have to buy the Airborne DLC. Luckily, you can use AI with your friends with only one person with the Airborne DLC

Summary:

MoW:AS2 is a great game held back by unmotivated developers. I give this a recommended because I always have fun playing with my friends against AI and within ourselves. Some promising mods I recommend are Free for All, Free for All Maps, Vietnam '65 and Vietnam '65 Frontlines AI, Robz Realism, #v a l o u r, ASV Warhammer 40k, Star Wars: Galaxy at War

A classic, long-running and hardcore WW2 RTS franchise which, to me, is the spiritual successor of [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/11480/Soldiers_Heroes_of_World_War_II/] Soldiers: Heros of WW2 [/url], a similar classic that came before Men of War franchise. MoW shares a good amount of similarities with Soldiers: HOWW2 due to the fact that both games run on the same engine and thus some assets were reused. But MoW really nailed it with so much more new content and a more modern graphics and compatibility with newer PCs. 

So to start off, this RTS game isn't for the faint hearted, there are more micromanagement than you'd expect in the units under your command. Each soldier has limited ammo that'd eventually run out without resupply, also they can die easily from a stray bullet or a well-placed shot. Each type of armored vehicle has varying armor thickness depending on its type or design, therefore every encounter requires a different approach to overcome, each mission and skirmish match can be a complete chaos, so you need to learn to keep your head cool and thoughts organized if you want to win the war and make your country proud. That being said, this is a RTS game where carefully planned and well executed tactics is rewarded greatly and recklessness or ignorance punished severely.

The game has lots of details that amazed me, the historical accuracy of the units set to show up in different years of the war is spot-on. Most vehicles would change their paintjob to adapt to the climate of the map. However, the biggest selling point for me and probably some other people is the active modding community that pumps out even more content to try out, just in case you already finished the rather short campaign missions. The only major gripe I have with this game is the horrible and borderline moronic AI that's been plaguing the units when I'm not directly controlling them or they're set to fire at will, tanks always prioritize infantry by switching to HE shells which is extremely stupid and pointless. This had always been the issue as well back in Soldiers: HOWW2, so it appears to be a fundamental AI bug in GEM engine. Furthermore, even though the game looks detailed at first glance, there are still some parts that just feels unfinished such as missing unit descriptions and unpolished parts like a few graphical issues with vehicle lights and fire effects. It's also worth noting that the game tends to crash now and then, so don't expect a stable run every time you play.

As retarded as the AI might had been, MoW 2 AS still offers you a pretty solid and hardcore WW2 RTS experience. If you're like me, a huge WW2 history nerd who also happens to love RTS games, this is the perfect game for you. If you're looking for a PTSD level experience, this game is also perfect due to the amazing sound effects and visuals. Just turn the master volume all the way up and let your whole family know that you're busy fighting a goddamn war, so that they'll never ask you to pause your game for a stupid meal ever again. ;)

I gave this game a try twice, and while it seems a very fun game with lots of potential at first, it quickly becomes tedious and annoying. There seems to be very little room for a cautious approach, you just need to rush in and throw more units at it than the enemy. It's probably a great game for some people, I'm just not one of them.

The only reason I made a Steam account way back when was to buy this game. After countless hours of watching Raptor and DiplexHeated videos, I begged my parents to let my buy this janky yet appealing RTS game on our old shity home computer. About 5ish years later and a total of 1 hour spent in multiplayer, I still (almost) enjoy Men of War AS2 as much as did when I first got it. 

I'd seriously recommend this game to any who's into RTS, strategy, or historically focused games in general. This game to me will and always will be a great time killer; letting me screw around in skirmish mode or the campaign with dozens of tanks, hundreds of infantry, and whole lot of explosives. As previously mentioned I spent hardly any time in multiplayer as it just isn't my thing nor the main appeal for me in RTS games. The real draw and the main reason I'd recommend this game to someone would have to be the mods. I've heard that the modding community for Men of War is not like what it used to be a number of years back, but honestly, that didn't stop me from enjoying the best of what the moding section had to offer. There are some real talented people who've made incredible detailed and highly scripted missions/mods that blows the official game itself out of the water. I've lost god knows how many hours playing through said missions and mods (plus a few years shaved off my life span probably) and have enjoyed myself thoroughly playing them. However, I cannot give an honest opinion about the game without mentioning the bugs. Fuck me the bugs. I have run into all sorts of issues/bugs through my playtime; everything from the blue spider soldiers, to missing textures, to the red exclamation marked ammo  that'll crash the game if fired. Not to mention the error messages you receive when said game crashes. I'd understand them better if they were written in Japanese I swear.  

As with basically any of game, It's most fun playing with a buddy or a group of lads. Grab a friend or two (if you have any) and I guarantee you'll be laughing, arguing, or freaking out about whatever situation/battle you might be in. The peak Men of War AS2 experience is an absolute cluster fuck on screen with dozens or sometimes even hundreds of units firing at one another, with the frame rate kicking the bucket every time something explodes.

Overall, I'd recommend this very entertaining game to anyone who's looking for something to play during this time of "staying indoors a lot", and especially to a history buff such as me. I would't recommend getting this game unless it's on sale, as even I think with the amount of hours I have that the price is a bit steep ($32,99 for those in Canada). You really don't need any of the DLCs to enjoy the core experience of this game, though some mods may require one or more to play. Thanks to whomever reads this whole "review", as it is my first on Steam.

Though MOW: AS2 can for sure be a pain in the ass at times, it is ultimately the most realistic and enjoyable RTS game on the market, with a plethora of expansive and unique DLCs as well as free Mods. If you're looking for an RTS game that breaks the standard formula of "large unit" tactics, than this is the RTS for you! 

Why? Well, MOW: AS2 allows you to form your own units, made up of Armor and Infantry, that of which is done via binding! Furthermore, you can individual control each and every unit, ranging from Infantry, all the way to airplanes and boats! Hell, every vehicles and infantryman even has their own inventory, where you can change their weapons, helmets, vests, and even their grenades!

If I had to give this game a one word definition, I would use the word "Dynamic" as everything in this game has a purpose and is important, as it all comes together to create a game not only fun and challenging, but realistic and focused... It's well worth the money you spend, especially with the DLCs and Mods.

Amazing War game, 10/10 would suggest buying. The graphics are stunning, everything about the game is just so well made, and if you get mods as well like the Galaxy at War Mod, you get so much more from the game, truly is timeless and I have no regrets buying this game.

I really like this game, while I wish there was some sort of version that incorporated logistics into it and made the campaign more than just the movie set missions, but those movie set missions are still good fun.

The editor is great to mess around in, I'd set up opposing armies of various strengths and make them clash for my amusement, it's like playing wars with legos as a kid. Made me happy, but I did feel like a bit of a loser after.
The multiplayer is interesting, people seem to be absolutely incredibly at it like with any RTS and I got stomped routinely.

Co-op is also super fun, figuring out ways to tackle the campaign on the hardest difficulty with your armchair general friends and micromanaging platoons at the start of a mission to try and eke out all that you can in those first critical moments to grab a foothold before the enemy crushes you is just a great time.

30 bucks feels like a lot though for the aging engine MOWAS runs on, and it feels unpolished at times, especially with direct controlling units. 

Oh and the mods are cool just to try I guess, there's a lot of interesting content for the game.

While i still really like the ambition and mechanics of this game, they are simply not polished enough the AI in particular leaves a lot to be desired at base game. Ive had numerous examples of the ai simply failing to execute basic functions. The pathfinding in particular is simply atrocious often having to take direct control of support units as they don't know how to cross bridges. Or units getting stuck on random objects. Additionally collision physics appear broken on ANY vehicle in this game ive noticed that if they collide with an object that is too strong for them to break through (eg. a support unit colliding with a tank), your vehicle will get stuck and spin in place near indefinitely until eventually finding a sweet spot to reset and allow you to give it orders/be able to take manual control again this can take a significant amount of time and sometimes render the unit useless as it does sometimes just get stuck disabling the unit and occasionally the vehicle it got stuck on again it just feels unpolished. Playing this game makes you feel more like a caretaker to your mentally challenged soldiers than a General directing an assault.

As an example for the ass pathing just play a game of skirmish or multiplayer on Shattered, spawn on the right side of the axis and order a support vehicle over the small hill down to the control point youll find your support vehicle will stop short just as the hill ends no matter where you told him to go the only way you can get him to move his broken ass is to take direct control of the unit and drive him manually to your designated point which is incredibly fun if youre in the middle of a fight trying to have your heavily suppressed units take down a tank while they are running out of ammo just because the unit got stuck.

The main reason i won't recommend it is as follows.  
-Most players are toxic.
-The multiplayer lobby is broken more often than it's working.
-There is a persistent desync error that will close a multiplayer game, mid game, rather than allow the game to catch up. (as much as there are online threads to fix it, they don't actually work, I've encountered it many times over the last few years, nothing fixes it)

So when the game works, it's fine. When it doesn't, it completely destroys your desire to play. Buy it when it's on sale, not full price, the game has been broken for a long time now and doesn't look like it'll be fixed any time soon

I want to love this game, I really do, but it won't let me. I mostly got it due to the amazingly done Warhammer 40k mod to play with friends and I like tactics games more than traditional RTS, HOWEVER, this game has a HUGE issue. This game is only x32 bit, what that means is it can ONLY USE 4GB OF RAM. If you use a program called "Large Address Aware" it allows it to use more than 4GB but it doesn't help much. What this means is this game will chug, get FPS laggy (it's not actual FPS drops), and eventually crash. The issue is the good mods ask too much of the game and it can't handle it. I suggest people get Call To Arms over this game, it is made by half of the same dev team and it built much better and for modern PCs. It also has a WWII DLC coming out C.T.A-Gates of Hell - Ostfront. C.T.A. is a much better game even though it's modern themed, it also has tons of workshop mods. If you want to risk it and see how well it runs for you, go ahead, but I have warned you. It runs like complete shit in MP. I have a Ryzen 5 3600, 1650 Super, & 16GB DDR4 @3200MHz. This game should run like a dream, but the devs don't give a shit to make it preform better on more modern PCs.
Save yourself. This game will crush your soul.

"pretty okie dokie" Original Review

Men of War Assault Squad 2 is a fun game that I have thoroughly enjoyed throughout the years, and was the main device for me to switch from an Xbox to a PC. After "pirating" it (downloading demos, I thought I was so smart as a 9 year old), I finally got it on steam.

Encounters are truly unique. Yeah, that's a dead term. The Division has "truly unique encounters" because it has the same 4 looters spawn walking menacingly down the street, but they're randomly ranked different. Assassins Creed Odyssey has "truly unique encounters" because the bounty hunter system has different character levels. What makes Men of War different?

The AI in Men of War, while not the best thinkers sometimes, can operate in any environment you give them. They are dependent on nodes or zones, only a proficiency that you give them (in speaking for the editor.) They will move to a cover, and if there is none available, will do all sorts of things to get to a state where they can have cover. They're very good in that aspect. The best thing I've enjoyed though is that they will not react with one set way. They will flank, suppress, mass charge or retreat purely by their choice, and while I'm not even sure this is intentional, it's a very interesting enemy to fight. It creates a very unique circumstance where I can remember what the enemy sends at me, but not how it will utilize it.

Controlling the units themselves is a lot of fun too. Setting up barricades, establishing front lines and preforming your own daring tasks against AI or your friends is a lot of fun. I remember using the KV-1 Heavy Tank to brutalize my friends Insolidious and TorpedoBob in a frontal assault, only for them to flank around me and capture my zones. Still haven't forgiven them for that one. It allows for a lot of options to play with.

Mods are great for this game, don't buy the Cold War DLC. I don't care how good the ratings get, the health bars alone make it doo doo
Just waiting for 1C to make an upgraded MOWAS game so it's not stuck in the 2010s

A phenomenal RTS centered around squad and individual unit management, with beautiful maps that will be leveled to the ground by the time you're done. Realistic tank combat, as well as a large variety of weapons (including big Japanese rockets and the "Karl Geralt" giant artillery piece) will keep you coming back for more. 
Only major gripe is that the base-game campaigns are all copy-paste. All follow the same pacing, mission type, etc., which is a bit boring. Unit pathing can also be an issue, and may lead to the death of a squad.
Overall: 8/10
Although Company Of Hereos 2 is well known, this game is clearly a better experience. A lot of fun with a great design its a must play for sure
